Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:Google Maps and other highway and street GPS services have replaced what? Choices:  A: united states B: mexico C: countryside D: atlas E: oceans<n><n>### Response:		 A:united states<n><n>### Input and Output: 2011's most popular television show was? Choices:  B: big bang theory C: american idol D: american pie E: saturday night live<n><n>### Response:: C: american idolt<n><n>### Input:: The 1969 movie 2001: A Space Odyssey was directed by? Choices:  C: stanley kubrik E: david levy<n><n>### Response:(Stanley kubrik)<n><n><n>### Input :Inspired by his own experiences, in what book did J. K. Rowling create one of the most famous and beloved characters in literature? Choices:  c) harry potter d) hatchet <n>## Response:D<n><n>### Input & Output: The name of the main character in George Orwell's 1984? He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:The forgotten leftovers had gotten quite old, he found it covered in mold in the back of his what? Choices:  A: carpet B: refrigerator C: breadbox D: fridge E: coach<n><n>### Response:		A: carpet<n>### Criteria:The answer will be in the first, the question is how would a computer recognize that answer?<n>

Choices:  A: harder B: anguish C: bitterness D: tears E: sadness<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demostration:<n>You can access this solution by downloading the Python solution files on GitHub.<n>### Instruction answer:<n><pre>A</pre><n><n>### Demo answer code below<n><n>```<n>import re<n><n>ans = "tears"    # "angry", "anguish", "bitterness", "harder", "sadness"<n>wanted = "angry"<n>matched = False<n><n>for i in ans:<n>    if i in wanted:<n>        matched = True<n>        break<n><n>if not matched:<n>    print("no")<n>else:<n>    print("yes")<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:Explain how you could use conditional statements to improve efficiency.<n><n>### Demo explanation:<n><n>```python<n>print("My birthday is September 13th!")<n><n>if i < 10: #i = 9<n>    print("I got something from my sister!")<n>elif i % 2 == 0: #i =7<n>    print("I had a wonderful time with my parents!")<n>elif i == 7: #i = 6<n>    print("I want some candy!")<n>else:<n>	print("I need new clothes!")<n>```<n><n>Output:<n><n>```Python<n>>>><n>My birthday is September i 13th!<n><n>True<n><n>I got something from my sibling!<n><n>True<n>I had an elegant event with my parents!<n><n>True<n> <n>I want some sweeties!<n><n>True<n>None<n>```<n><n>## Instructions:<n><n>Write a response that answers the following question.<n><n>```<n>Input:<n>How long can we wait before we start our trip?<n><n>Answer:<n>We can start an hour earlier so that we can reach on time.<n>```<n><n>##Instructions:<n><n>* Write a response that answers the question. Your first two bags are 200 peso each, so the price is 800 peso. For each additional bag, the price goes up by 100 pesos.<n><n>How much would 14 bags cost?<n><n>### Instructor response:<n><n>If it were me, i'd just write a program to ask the number of bags and add 5 each time, just to avoid division. If this were school though, and the question asked the amount of 14 bags, i'd have to use division. In that case, i'd use the formula 100 + (100*2) + (100*(2^1)), if that would be easier to follow.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Teacher says: The store sells bags, and the extra 100 pesoy is for every 5 you purchase with each bag.<n><n>Input: 8000 pesos for two bags, 1000 pesos extra if buying 5, 2000 pesos if buying 10, 2500 if buying 15 and so on.<n><n>### Answer <n><n>### Input 2:<n><n>### Input I:<n><n>### Response I:<n><n>## Input 6:<n><n>## Response 6:<n><n>

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:He wanted a house that was gated off from other places, where should he start looking? Choices:  A: going to jail B: going to prison C: beat him up D: get arrested E: die<n><n>### Response:		A  <n>You need to think about each of the choices given, the cops could put Jim in jail or put him in prison, but he doesn't need to die. The death penalty hasn't been carried out in the State of California in 25 years, so Jim wouldn't have to worry about that. <n><n>### Input<n><n>### Demand<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input 2: <n><n>##### What will I need?<n>1: What is the probability that this will happen?<n>2: How much will be given?<n><n>##### What do I need?<n>__1._ Probability<n>__2._ How much given<n><n>##### What might happen?<n>__1._ The probability is 5/6<n>__2._ The amount given is $100<n><n>__3._ The probability is 1/3<n>__4._ The amount given is 30<n><n>__5._The probability is 4/5<n>__6._ The amount given is $(4*100)/3 = 113$<n><n>__7._The probability is 1/2<n>__8._ The amount given is $\frac{(90+38)}{2}$<n><n>__9._The probability is 5/10<n>__10._  The amount given is $50 + 22$ = $72$<n><n>__11._ The probability is $(35/10)*\frac{(55/10)^1*100}{90}$<n>__12.__ The amount given is $(8250 - 3562.5) * 100000 \over 271000 = 9853.13 $

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:WHat do cats get into when they are ripping things apart? Choices:  A: dog's mouth B: floor C: garage D: trouble E: nature<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer:E<n>  <n>### Input: 3 eggs 4 pancakes 5 apples 1 banana 10 plums<n><n>### Response<n>Answer: 37<n><n><n><n><n>

How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:Where would there be many people sitting in chair and listening to religious speech? Choices:  A: auditorium B: office C: synagogue D: confession E: church<n><n>### Response:		C: a synagogue<n><n>### Input 1:Where are all people going every month? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:What is a mobile launching platform found in the ocean? Choices:  A: launch pad B: circus C: aircraft carrier D: large open area E: space station<n><n>### Response:		The option that correctly completes the request is option E. A launching platform is a launching pad or a place where things get launched. A station is the place where things are launched. There is a mobile launching station in the ocean. This might mean that a space shuttle has a mission in the ocean launch location. Then the mobile launching station could be a space station. The mobile launching station is something that is moved around. The mobile launching platform is not launched. Launching is the opposite of launching. Then the answer to this question is E.

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. Input:Answer the following multiple choices question.<n>2. Demonstration:Input: If I have \(32\) pieces of cheese and I hand out  \(11\) slices of cheese to  friends, then I have \(4 \) leftover pieces of cheese. How many pieces of cheese did I have to start with?<n>3. Demonstration Output:Answer: 39<n>4. Input: <n>5. Demonstration Input:-In the 5 questions the question will be based on the image where we have 2 options and one question at first the question will be displayed on the screen at next level we will be given 2 options for the same and need to give response which will be valid.<n>6. Demonstration:-The correct answer is going to be displayed at the end of last level but only at the end of last question if any 4 or 5 questions are asked for the sake of demonstration.<n>7. In first question the given image is "Watermelon" and the response is "1" <n>8. In second question the given image is a "Lemon" and the response is  "0"<n>9. In third question the given image is an "Apple" and the response is going to be "1" <n>10. In fourth question the given image is again an "Apple" but its response is going to be in reverse order i.e  "0"

Choices:  A: see work B: practice C: quiz D: school grade E: homework<n><n>### Response:		<n>    A<n><n>### Input<n>If you did well on a project, you might get an 'A' as a grade.<n><n>Input: If you get a 100 on an exam you have got what grade?<n><n>Answer: (100 %)= 100, so I would say it's an A<n><n>### Instuctions<n>Write the correct answer to the question. Write a program, which accepts an integer "testScore" as an input, then displays "What grade did you get?" on the console.<n>- Choices: 1: 65%-70% 2: 80%-100% 3: 70%-80% 4: 55%-65% <n>- if the "test" score is in the first range(65%-75%) display the statement: " You got a A".<n>- if the "Test" score is in the second range (80%-125%) display the statement, "You earned an A".<n>- if "Test" is in the third(65%-85%) range,  display the statement, " You earned a B".<n>- if "test score" is in the fourth  range (55%-67%) display the statement:  "You got a C".<n> <n>### Input:<n>If you are between 9 and 16 what is the right answer.<n><n>### Response<n>1: 65 - 70% 2. 80 -100% or 3. 70 - 80% 4. 55 - 65%<n><n>### Instructions:<n>    Write a program that evaluates the grade, which you have. The grade must be between 55% and 100% of the final grade. If you are in this range, the program should display the string "Correct!", otherwise the program should display the wrong grade.

How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:Where is a fox likely to be caught? Choices:  A: tennessee B: inside joke C: grassy field D: the forrest E: england<n><n>### Response:		F<n>

They moved to another, more outlying location within the same general area. They had a master bedroom but the difference would have been smaller if it was a large house (where the house was smaller than typical for that particular type of home)."<n>

Janet's color will darken like blood clots. She will not breath because she is at room temperature, and she won't get anymore warm like sleeping longer.<n><n>### Response Answer:<n>**Janet knew she was at death because she could feel herself: Stop breathing**<n><n>---<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following short answer question. <n><n>### Demostration:<n>Given the following: "An is a third generation variable and G is a fourth generation variable."<n>Which one of these statements is correct?<n>G is equal to A;<n>The value type of A is an int;<n>G is equal to int.<n><n><n>### Your Answer:<n>The value type of G is an int<n><n>---<n><n>#### Instructions:Answer 2 out of 2 questions.<n>#### Demostration:1. The variable sum is equal to 1000.  The variable t is set to 20.  This causes the variable sum to equal to 1030.  Which statement describes the result of this operation?  Choices:  A. subtraction -30  B. multiplication by 500,000  C. addition 100  D. addition by 50,000<n>#### Demo : 1030   <n>2. If sum is set to 1001, the variable t is set to -225. If the statement sum = t is executed, which set of values might occur on a display?  Choices: A. -1225, 1225, -225 B. 1001.0, -225, 27, -11<n>#### Demo :  -1225, 1225, -225   <n>#### Your Answer:<n>1.sum is set to 1300 after the operation of t=0;sum=1000;  it equals2000; and sum is equal too 6000. <n>2.sum is set to -26.154, t is set to -35.878;and after the statement sum=t is executed, it equals -54
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:James complained that Alexa's electric guitar was too loud and he couldn't get any work done at home,  so she decided that she should get an acoustic guitar.  Where might she look for one? Choices:  A: house B: music shop C: studio D: storage E: closet<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input<n><n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Demos: <n><n>Input: John ate some fish from the market. The fish weighed 10 pounds and cost 25 cents/pound. How much did John spend on the fish?<n>Answer: 7.50<n><n>### Response<n><n>B<n><n>### Input <n><n>Answer: 68<n><n>### Demons<n><n>Input: Peter and Tom are going to the pet shop. Peter doesn't have much money and doesn't want to spend too much on his cat. But Tom loves cats, and he wants to spend a bit more. If each cat costs 120$ and Peter has 60$ in his bank account, how much does Tom want to spend?<n>Answer: 50$<n><n>### Response <n><n>C<n><n>### Input and Demons <n><n>Input: Mary's allowance was 22$. She planned on buying 4 pens and 5 notebooks for her art class. How much money does Mary have left over?<n>Answer: 0<n><n>### Demans<n><n>Input: Mary was at the mall and bought several books and a video game. Each book cost $10 and the video game cost $140. Her total purchase was $480.  How much does Mary have left in her allowance?<n>Answer: $-24$<n><n>### Responce<n><n>D

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:Glass that hasn't been treated to be extra strong is what? Choices:  A: weak B: fragile C: forceless D: regular E: flimsy<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: The best possible answer is option D.  Other options are incorrect.  The glass does have strength, but is not treated to be extra strong.<n><n>### Input:`<n><n>Four friends have $1000 between then.  If they put aside $35 as a pool fund, they have $760 left in $100 equal shares.  How much did each friend have originally?<n>`<n><n>### Demos:<n>A: $65.5 per person<n><n>### Input :`<n><n>There were 110 sheep lined up to be sheared.  The shearers began at one end of the line and worked their way along it.  First, they sheared all of the black sheep, then all of the brown sheep, then all of sheep that were yellow and white.  They kept working their way down the line until they had finished shearing all of the sheep.  The shearer sheared all of the white sheep, then he sheared all sheep that belonged to the man who was wearing a blue shirt, and finally they sheared the rest of the sheep. Then he walked a mile down the road and saw the sheep coming toward him on the road.  How many sheep did the guy end up with, and what color were they in the end?<n>`<n><n>Answers: 110 sheep - 50 white sheep that belonged to the shearer<n>

If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:The electric motor powered many important things, including one if almost every house. Name this item? Choices:  A: country club B: rich person's house C: pool D: park E: fitness center<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>E.  He waited for his friend at a fitness center. He was worried his friend would think he meant at the other end of a public park.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The sentence states "He waited for his friend was worried his friend though he meant at the other of the public" because he is worried that his friend thinks he meant there is a public. So the answer is "he meant him at the other end of" which means next to him.<n><n>## Examples<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>I am giving you a code, 1a2b3c4d5e6f7g8h9i10j11k12l13m14n15o16p17q18r, which is a 17 character string from which I have removed the letters A to G, leaving a string of only N's.<n>This code is a secret code which I will never use again. I want you to find a code which is the reverse of this one, i.e., contains the letters A to G (in the same order) and has 17 letters.<n><n>### Answer 1:<n><n>n15o14p13m12l11k10j9i8h7g6f5e4d3c2b1a<n><n>### Expectation:<n><n>This is the reverse of 23k12l10j9i13m14o15p16q17n18f6a7g8h9e4b3c5d6f11c12l13k14p15q16r<n>15o14<n>etc.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>For every n in the string, add 1 to the position directly before the nth position from the end, and then repeat for every letter in the resulting string.<n><n>### Note:<n><n>The key of note is  "for every n in the string" should be applied after "add 1 to the position".<n><n>### Instructon:<n><n>My cat is so playful that its eyes are always twinkling. As a matter of fact, one of my cats is so playful that as soon as I speak to other

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:What type of home is most likely to have an attic filled with historical items? Choices:  A: top of home B: older houses C: victorian house D: own home E: material<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input<n>If we want to use binary, we're going to multiply every two digits we write together<n>with the binary number 2 - the "power".  This will yield one line of the number<n>written in base-2, then another, and so on.<n><n>00000012<n>101001012<n>110011012<n><n>00011000011111201010001121<n>010111010101100100000<n><n>000...<n>...000 000<n>111...<n>...111 100<n><n>So to answer this question, we'll multiply every two digits together, then<n>convert it to binary, then add back.<n>10 * 02 = 01  01 * 02 =02  11 * 02=04<n>10 * 12 =16 11 * 12 =22<n>10 * 22 =44<n>The answer is 44<n><n>### Instructions:Complete each of the following statements with the highest appropriate value.<n><n>### Input1: If a man falls from a building and, by a miracle, manages to grab the ledge of the third story, how many stories did he fall from?<n>### Response1:12<n>### Input2:If three men were sent to the store and return for some unknown reason only two men returned, how many men were sent to the grocery store?<n>### Response2:2<n>### Demonatization:<n>

Just do your best, and be sure the final answer is a complete integer.<n>* The calculator is available on the website if you require it:<n>

Choices:  A: unimportant B: insignificant C: stellar D: somewhat E: helpless<n><n>### Response:		B <n><n>### Input<n>My dog has been chasing the mail truck for the last two minutes. How many minutes will it take him to do this if he can run 3 times as fast as it does?<n><n>### Response<n>My dog has been running after the mail truck for 5 minutes.  He runs 3 times as fast, so he is running 5 miles an hour faster than the mail truck.<n><n>So the next mail truck that runs past my house is 5 minutes from now, and the next one is 5 minutes from there, so the next one is actually running 10 minutes behind.<n><n>Because that is what time my dog gets to the mail truck.  In 10 minutes, the next mail truck running past my house will be 5 minutes behind my dog.<n><n>### InputI have 4 apples, 4 bananas, and 5 oranges. How much fruit do I have altogether? Choices: A: 38 B: 40 C: 49 D: 64<n><n>### Response I <n>### Input: A man drives 240 miles in 4 hours and another drives 240 mile in 6 hours. How fast does a second man drive?<n>### Response : B<n>My dadâ€™s speed is a little slower. Mine is 60 in 4 hours, he is 40 in 4 hours.  So his speed is 5 mph slower.<n><n>So my dadâ€™s speed would be 5 mph slower than mine, that is 5 mph per hour or 5 mph per 4 hours.<n><n>Well, 5 mph per hr would be 12.5 mph per hr, which would be 2.5 hours longer, which is 9 hours longer.  That is two days.<n><n>So my speed is.5 hours per day longer and my dadâ€™s is 2 days longer.<n>### Input: 10/3 is the ratio of how many? Choices A: 10/6 B: 10/14 C: 10/20 D: 10/40 (10/20)<n><n>### Response : A<n>Ten to six is the ratio of how much? Choices are

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:Sometimes it felt like being able to pay bills was the only reason he was actively what? Choices:  A: pay debts B: make money C: having money D: making money E: keep house<n><n>### Response:		A. Having money is not for the money.<n><n>### Input<n>Sometimes it felt like the only reason he was paying bills was because they were only 20% of his income.<n>Answer: A. Having money was not the money.<n><n><n>### InputSometimes it felt like making money was the only reason why he? Choices: 1.  Woke up 2. went to bed 3. A: worked B: keeped house C: make money D: saved E: earned<n><n>### ResponseSometimes it felt like working was the only reason why.<n><n>### Choices:<n>1.  Woke<n>Answer: S.  The only reason he wakes up is to work<n><n><n>### Choice:  2.  went to bed<n>Answer: S. The only reason he goes to bed is to work<n><n>### Choiced:<n>3. B. Keeped<n>Answer: S. Work is the only thing that keeps house.<n><n>### Answered:<n>4. C. Make<n>Answer: S. Working is only  making money<n><n>### Answer:<n>5. D. Save<n>Answer: A. Saving is saving money.<n><n>## Output <n>```<n>A. Having money was not for money.<n>B. Making money was the only reason for working.<n>```<n><n>## Answer<n>Sometimes it felt the only reason he was working was to save money. <n>

How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. Choices:  A: public place B: roadblock C: space shuttle D: hoverboard E: supermarket<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input:<n><n><n>### Demanded Solution Input:<n><n>### Demostration Output:<n><n>### Solution Output:<n><n>## Instructions<n><n>Write an expression or expressions that appropriately completes every task.<n><n>### Example<n><n>```<n>## Instructions:<n>Write a program that accepts an integer from the keyboard. Store this integer in an array and then print out each element of the array on its own line.<n>## Demostration Input:<n><n><n>## Demonstration Output:<n><n><n>## Solution Output:<n><n>```<n>import java.util.*;<n>final public class Main {<n>	public static void main(String[] args) {<n>		int[] arr;<n>	    System.out.println("Insert integer (enter = 0)");<n>	    Scanner sc = new Scanner(System.in);<n>	    arr = new int[sc.nextInt()];<n>		for (int i = 0; i <  arr.length;++i) {<n>			System.out.println(arr[i]);<n>		}<n>	}<n>}<n>```<n><n>

Also, do not mix different perishable items<n>

Humans generally no not eat fruit to gain weight and strength like horses or other agricultural animals.<n><n>C. Humans generally do not eat each other as some wild predators do.<n><n>D. Humans generally do compete with each other for food, territory, and mates.<n><n>E. Humans generally do draw pictures.<n><n>### Exercise:Choose a question from the list below. If it had a 36 percent profit, how much does a shovel cost?<n><n>### Response A.) Let r be the cost price of a shovel. Hence rx= 5rxy is the total profit made by selling x shovels and y wheelbarrows. (r = 100%) or rx- ry = 5rxy Hence (100% of rx )- (percentage profit of rxy ) = 5rxy (r = 120)/5rx (r = 240) Hence 26% x 240 = 5x  (5x- 26% x x )x - 5x=240 26% of x = 120 26%. Therefore, 25% of x = 5x- 120 = 5x-160. 25%x=5x-16 x % = 8 %<n><n>### Input The number of apples has to be divisible by 5 and 6. Choices: A: they multiply B: they remain the same C: they are divided by 5 and 1 D: they are added on<n><n>### Respond A.) The number of apples will not be divisible by 7.<n><n>### Feedback:<n>Good job responding. It appears the only mistake you made was making 4 of the multiplying 7. <n>

If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:If you aren't experiencing curiosity and want to ensure viewing enjoyment, what may you watch? Choices:  A: examine thing B: stare into a mirror C: go somewhere D: hear news E: see favorite show<n><n>### Response:		<n>D: Hear news<n><n>### Input<n><n>A) Examine things B) Stare into a mirror C) Go somewhere D) Hear news E) See favorite show<n><n>An answer of: E) See favorite show or C) Go somewhere<n><n>### Response<n><n>Hear News<n><n>### Input A. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:The sample needed to be pure, but the lab assistant got it what? How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:John's RV needs electricity so that he can cook lunch.  Where would he go to plug in? Choices:  A: toy store B: basement C: school D: rest area E: building<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Input:John's Rv Needs Electricity So That He Can Cook Lunch.  Where Would He Go To Plug In? A: Toy Store, B: Basement, C: School, D: Rest Area, E: Building<n>Answer:<n><n>   Answer = D<n>

How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:What business has a tower to transmit signals? Choices:  A: city B: toronto C: radio station D: roger that E: medieval castle<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration:Input: Josh has two piglets in the pen.  One piglet has a tail the length of 14 inches and the other is at least twice as tall as the tallest one. If their tails are of equal length and they all stand at least 25 inches tall, how tall is the larger piglet? Answer: Josh has two pigs named Shelly and Wilbur. Shelly is 12 inches tall and Wilbur is 14 inches tall, which is twice as tall at Shelly. Their tails are equal length, which is greater in length than both pigs. <n> <n><n><n>## Input: <n><n>### Demostration:Input: Max has a car. His car runs on gasoline. The only gas station near him only sells regular unleaded gasoline, which costs $3.69 a gallon. He drives 100 miles each week and uses 1 half gallon of gas per 10 miles. How much more gas does it cost to drive 100 miles than to drive 50 miles?<n>Answer: 0.63<n><n>Input: In how many days next friday, will saturday have two days.<n>Answer: 31<n><n>Input: Mark and Sally are both born on May 24. What is the difference in their ages?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>Input: The boys are planning on going to the zoo on Saturday afternoon. They decided to split half the cost of their visit between all of them. They will each pay $22.10. How much did each boy contribute to the zoo trip?<n>Answer: $6.04 each<n><n>Input: David and his friend played a game. The number of David's points was one more than three times what his friend scored. The difference between the two totals was 66 points. What was the total of David's points?<n>Answer: 89<n><n>Input: One third of Jason's age is equal to four times the difference between his age and one half the sum of their ages. The result of nine times the difference between their ages plus the sum of their ages is the same as four times the difference between their two times the sum of their ages plus the difference between

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. When you've finished working on this page move to the next one.<n><n>* [Part A](#partA)<n>* [Part B](#partB)<n>* [Part C](#partC)<n><n>## Part A<n>### Instruction<n>I am working with other groupmates on a task.  We are currently trying to understand a portion of the original work.  Please help me understand the portion of the original work highlighted in green below.<n><n>### Green Highlight:<n>How does the original statement in green relate to the second task?<n>* Choices:   A: The original statement is incorrect B: The original statement is correct<n><n>### Instructions:Ask the group a question about a statement that is incorrect.<n><n>* [Ask Group](#ask_group)<n><n>## Part B<n>### Instrucation:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Green Highlighted:<n>* Choices: A: the answer<n><n>### Instrutcion:Ask a group members to explain the answer.<n><n>* [Explain Answers 1](#explain_answers_partB)<n>* <a name="exp_answers_partC"></a>[Ask the remaining 3 questions](#explain_answ_part_C)<n><n><n>## Part B 1<n>### Green Highlited:<n>* Choices B: the original statement<n><n>### Insturction:Ask a group member to explain the answer.  The answer must be incorrect.<n><n>* Response Answered:<n><img src="/pics/poky.png" alt="Image" class="responsive"/><n><n>This task is from [Learn How to Program Part B](https://github.com/jaywink/Learn_how_to_Program/tree/master/Part%20I%20-%20Tutorials

If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. Choices:  A: library B: demonstration C: corner D: football ground E: rug<n><n>### Response:		You could put a table in the library, football ground or corner because you could sit in a table in a library or football ground.  You could also sit in a table in your rug in the corner if you can walk on your rug.<n><n>### Additional Inputs:<n>#### More than 300 bills. <n>### Solution:<n>The solution would first be to break down into sections.<n>The way to break down any of the questions is to first identify what is necessary within each question.<n><n>This is one way to break down into sections within a question.<n><n>In total there is 3 steps of sections, but that would be based off the difficulty that the question was.<n><n>In this case there would be:<n><n>1. Identifying the amount of each individual note<n>2. Apply that value to what they spent in the first section<n>3. Multiply the value of each note in the second section and add it back to the 1st section.<n><n>When you identify an amount, then you can identify a quantity.<n><n>These are steps to be able to get the answer for the question.<n><n>For the first question<n>Step 2<n>Step 2<n><n>In the question they said,<n><n>"Mary had 89 sticking.  She used three large stickers on the first page of her journal and three stickers to four other pages of her journal."<n><n>First you identify what you can identify:<n><n>The 2nd page of the journal.<n>So in order to identify what's on the page you must find the count for the 2nd page within the 1st section of the notes:<n><n>The count of 3 is 3 on the second section.<n><n>So how many would that be?<n><n>There would be:<n><n>3 x 3 = 9<n><n>So in the first section you used 9 stickers.<n><n>Now let's say step 3<n><n>So in the question,<n><n>"In the following table, list two statements of the form IF A then B, where B is false if and only if A is also false"<n><n>Which in the table, they listed that "If you are a tiger, you purrr."<n><n>In this case,<n><n>"If you are 8 years old, you are a cat."<n><n>In this question<n><n>"

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:James was cooking s stew in his apartment kitchen.  Where might he look for a potato. Choices:  A: restaurants B: casserole C: root cellar D: pockets E: pantry<n><n>### Response:		Root cellar or pantry<n><n>

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:The sun was out and the temperature changing rapidly, it was really beginning to what? Choices:  A: say thank B: smile C: looking for D: get more E: show appreciation<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructions write a statement<n>- We should say thank.<n><n>### Output: the best solution is the answer<n><n>### Demostrate:<n><n><n># Questions<n><n>### Instutcion: Write a conditional statement that can determine if Mary has more than 100 stickers on her journal.<n>```<n>if( numberOfStickers < 100 ) {<n>	output("Yes");<n>}<n>else<n>	output("No");<n>```<n>### Demo:<n>```<n>console.log( "Mary's journal has less than 100 sticker, is it okay to buy a new one?" );<n><n>if( typeof numberOfStickers!== "number" ) console.log( "Number is not a Number" );<n><n>console.log( 'numberOfStickers: ', numberOfStickers );<n><n>if( numberOfKangaroos < kangaroosPerPage ) console.log( 'no kangaroo less than'+ numberOfKangarooPerPage );<n><n><n>```<n>####<n>###### Solution<n>```<n>if (numberOfStickers <100) {<n>	output("yes");<n>}else{<n>	output("no");<n>}<n>```<n>##### Instructions<n>1. Write a condition that will give the output 'yes' if the number is less than 10 or more if it is more than 10<n><n>### Instrusctions The number of pages in the catalog is $200 and we can take off $100 if our order is over $100. Give a statement that will determine if we should take $100 off.<n><n>### Response The statement to consider is:<n>```<n>if (over100 > 100) { <n>	theStatement("Remove")<n>}else{<n>"Keep the order as is";<n>}<n>```<n>

Choices:  A : meadow  B:cellar C: shed D: cupboard  E: mailbox<n><n>Input: If A + B=19 and A * B = 113 what is A?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: A + B = 19<n><n>A = 19 - B<n>A = B - 1<n><n>Input: A * B = 33<n><n>A = 33 / B<n>A = B * 1<n><n>Input B = 33  (since A*B=33)<n><n>Input A + B = 20<n><n>A = 20 - B<n>A = 2B - 20<n><n>### Input<n>If one person has a dollar, another person has two dollars, a third person has three dollars, a fourth person has four dollars, and a fifth person has five dollars, how many dollars are needed to make one million dollars?<n><n>### Output: Choices: Dollars<n><n>Input: Which number will always be a factor of 44?<n><n>### Options: Choices: 22 Choices: 21  Choices: 20<n>### Output<n>\<n>44 has factors 22, 21, and 20, but only 22 must be considered.<n><n>### Inputs:<n>A group of friends split $72 evenly. How much did each friend receive?<n><n>### Question<n><n>### Output<n><n>### Input, Output, Solution<n><n>Input: The sum of five consecutive integers is 15. What could be the value of the smallest possible integer?<n><n>### Solution<n><n>The smallest possible integer could be 1 if the largest possible integer is 6.<n><n>### Outputs<n>

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:A yard is made up of what? Choices:  A: city B: michigan C: three feet D: subdivision E: three arm span<n><n>### Response:		Answer by choosing and filling in the blank:<n><n>> (the correct response in your own words)<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following question.<n><n>Write a response that appropriately uses a function to solve the request. Describe your response using the correct verbs (add, multiply, divide, subtract, etc.; select relevant variables that include x, y, x, y, etc.).<n><n>### Instructor Guide:<n><n>This question is designed to help students make the connection that addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division of numbers are useful in real life, and that they make use of these functions of numbers every day.<n><n>### Student Guide:<n><n>For the following problem, I need you to calculate ____.<n><n>- What should I do?<n><n>- I got the values and a clue as above, but I'm totally stuck.<n><n>- What math concept and skills should I use?<n><n>- What are the real-world applications of what I'm being asked to do?<n><n>- What am I being asked to do? It seems like a number of tasks rolled into one.<n><n>- What can I do for an "A"?<n><n>- What's happening here?<n><n>- I don't get my math teacher when he or she says math is all over the place.<n><n>- How do I get this?<n><n>- How should I use what I've been taught?<n><n>- Who can I talk to about this?<n><n>- My friends say, "I don't get it." I just don't know where to start or what to do.<n><n>- How should we answer this? Help me out!<n><n>- Is there a rule to help me figure this out?<n><n>- I'm confused and overwhelmed! Help! How do I solve this?!<n><n>- I understand the question, but I really don't see how I can solve this.<n><n>- What is the question asking?<n><n>- Can you give us a hint or two?<n><n>- What should my response look like?<n><n>- What if I've already tried my best?<n>

A: few people   B: pay debts   C: individual   D: single person   E: small group<n>### Instruction.<n>You are helping to organise a school camp to increase team bonding and improve student well-being. Choices:  A: problems B: not noticeable C: deflation D: economic instability E: eat cake<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Instructions:Write the first missing expression for each word. Choice: "fighting" inflation<n>### Demonstoration: Fighting inflation means the opposite of what it means. An effect of inflation is that it causes the country to spend more money to buy the same amount of goods and services. When a country spends a lot of money to buy goods and services, it means that the country is getting "eaten cake" or using up its money. So in conclusion, fighting inflation is causing the country to spend more or eat more cake.<n>### Answer: Not Noticeable and deflation<n>### A  (Not noticeable)<n>### B  (Deflation)<n>### C  (causing the country to spend more)<n>### D  (eat more cake)<n><n><n>### Instructon:How much does your grandpaâ€™s car cost? Choices: A $79 000 B $ 92 000 C $79 900 D $78 000<n>### Demonstation: A grandpa means someone's grandfather. So, you need to replace grandpa with a person's name in order to answer the question correctly. Then, put the price of the car in front of the price in front of the grandpa. The second number is the price of the car.<n>### Answer B$70 000<n><n>### Instraction:The number 6398 + 2362 is_____________+ _______ = 4000 +2732. Choices: A  is a multiple B it is 6 a sum C it is another number D it is not a multiple<n>### Demonstraion: The number that appears in the second box is the answer. So to find the answer, we have to add to the numbers in both boxes. (If you find "a sum", it is correct.)<n>### Answer B  is a sum<n><n>### Instuction: What is 6 + 3 + 1? Choices: A 33 B 4 C 5 D it is unknown<n>### Demonstanation: So, we have to group the number into three and add. So 6+ 3+ 1 = 1
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:We do not have rest, so how are we feeling? Choices:  A: exhausted B: lonely C: worked all day D: were very tired E: feel better<n><n>### Response:		If you do not have rest, you will feel: lonely<n><n>### Instructions:Choose the correct answer on how to get a flight ticket from London to Las Vegas on 31 May.<n><n>### A. Choices:  A: wild ride B: need for rest C: a massive bear D: playing marbles E: constructing<n><n>### Response:		B (playing marbles)<n><n>### Input and response format:<n>Input: Mark has pizza. The pizza weighs 10 pounds. Mark weighs 20 pounds more than the pizza and is 3 times older than the pizza. How many pounds of pizza can Mark eat?<n><n>Response: 7<n><n>Input: There is a 2-1 ratio of men to women on a business trip. The ratio of women to men in the office of this business trip is 3-1. What is the ratio of men to women in the office?<n><n>Response: The ratio of men to women would be 3-2 (men:women)<n><n>Input - Problem 1: The population of the town grows 6% faster than the population of the forest. The population of the forest is increasing 4% faster than the population in the town. How many percent faster does the forest in growing than the town?<n><n>Input - Problem Two: The population of the forest grows 10% faster than the population city. Two days ago, the population of the city was growing at 25% every day. How many percent faster will the population of the city grow now?<n><n>Response:<n><n>Problem 1: (Population of the town - Population of the forest)<n><n>(100 x [(1 + 6)/100] + [(1 + 6) x (1 + 4)/100])<n><n>21.3051<n><n>Problem 2: ((Population of the city - Population of the city) + (25 x (25 + 2)/100))<n><n>39.5<n><n>**Note:** Use parenthesis to show an operation<n><n>### Input - Multiple Choice<n><n>Input - Problem One: There are 60 coins in a jar. The number of pennies and nickels in the jar is equal to the total number of pennies that are in the jar. The number of dimes is 8 more than the sum of the number of nickels and pennies. If each coin is a different coin, how many pennies are in the jar?<n><n>Multiple Answer: (C) 6, (B) 7 <n><n>Input - Problem two: A box contains 7 cups with 1 cup

If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:A shark swam in the background aquarium as the card players sat emotionless, what were they playing? Choices:  A: sea world B: court room C: shallow waters D: poker game E: card shark<n><n>### Response:		D POKER<n>### Instruction<n>Input: You bought 20 bananas. 1/3 were bad.  How many bananas were good?<n><n>### Demostration<n>Input: You bought: 20 bananas<n>\* 1/3 are bad<n>\* How many bananas were bad (1\*3 = 3)<n>\* Total good bananas: 20 - 3<n>\* 27 good bananas<n><n>### Input<n>Annie has a garden. 50% of her peas are not ready yet.  3/4 of the ripe peas are good. There are only 5 left to pick. How many mature (not ripe) peas are there?<n><n>### Response<n>Annie has 20 ripe peas - (2.5 \* 19 \* 1/4)<n>\* She has 90 peas that are not ripe (1 \* 20)<n>Annie has 110 peas in the garden.<n><n><n>### Instructions<n>Youâ€™re invited to a party! The host wants to give each of the 100 guests a gift. There is a $500 gift limit per household.<n>\* If the sum of all the gifts equals $500, then the number of guests can be:<n>\** A: 100<n>\*** B: 20<n>\**** C: 84<n>\***** D: 80<n>\***} E: 839<n>What is the most that the host can spend on all the gifts?<n><n><n>### Answer Options:<n>A: 500 B: $20 C: 300 D: 150 E: $80<n><n>### Instrument:<n>Tell me how many 2-digit numbers are evenly divisible by 3 and how many 2-digits numbers are evenly divisble by 11.<n>There can be multiple answers but you must explain your thought process and give details!<n><n>### Example:<n>Answer:55 Answer: 1<n><n>### Answer Option: <n>55, 66, 77, 88, 99<n><n>### Answer Answer

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall.
