His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:What is the worst outcome of an injury? Choices:  A: cause death B: cause bleeding C: falling down D: become infected E: claim insurance<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>E: claim insurance<n>### Input:How is math related to the game of tennis? Choices: A: By predicting winners B: by calculating points C: by predicting the next shot D: by calculating strategy E: by predicting winning streaks<n>### Response:A:By predicting winners<n>### Instruction<n>What is the average of $98, $100 and $109?<n>### Demonstraion:<n>Answe: $3<n>### Instruction 2: What is the median of $35, $25, $15 and $54?<n>### Demo:<n>Ans:  25<n>### Instruction No. 3: What is the Mode of $1, 4, 5, 3, 8, and $16?<n>### Demo:<n>$${<n>\begin{aligned}<n>& \rm{{Mode}} = \rm{{Finding\ the\ middle\ value}} \\<n>& \rm{{Number\ of\ items}} = 6 \\<n>& \rm{\{\ {1,4,5,3,8,16}\}}\rm{{with\ 7\ numbers}} \\<n>& \frac{7}{2}\times\rm{\left(\rm{{1,4,5,3,8,12}\rm\right)}}+{{9\rm}} \\<n>& \left[ {1,4,4.5,3,5,5.8,8} \right]+9<n>\end{aligned}}$$<n><n>$\rm{{Mode}}=\rm{{4.5}}$<n>\#37634737\<n>\#0<n><n>### Instructions 4: Answer the following multiple choice question:<n><n>During the day, a person's body temperature normally increases. However, during the night, it normally decreases.<n><n>At first light, a person's temperature is usually 80 degrees Fahrenheit. After 10 hours, a person's current temperature is 65 degrees.<n><n>When the sun sets a person's temperature 3 hours after sunset is 92 degrees. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. Choices:  A: interesting B: fun C: joyful or painful D: very important E: free<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>My first instinct may just be to add more interesting activities in learning the material we're studying. I wouldn't choose D because learning is never free. Even when someone is given a free education, they still must do a lot of work themselves in order to comprehend the material. I feel that learning material that is too uninteresting may be a better way to not like learning at all because it takes the joy out of learning to where it may not be considered an enjoyable activity anymore, and it would be better if there was something that was more fun to do rather than simply doing homework. I would also choose A because if the curriculum and the teaching of the class are boring to someone who is learning, they will most likely not enjoy learning no matter what they're doing. It takes someone with skill and motivation to be a good teacher who can engage students, and the teacher could try a lot of different activities to try to get the students interested in the material to try to improve their classroom experience.<n><n><n>

Remember to include the correct order of operations.<n><n>|Input Numbers|Number |<n>|-|-|<n>|58 * 11 =8 |58 *11 = 652|<n>|3 - 2 + 5 = 8|3 + 1 - 5 = 2|<n>|5 - 4 = 3|5 - (4 + 7) = 3|<n>|-27 \ 9|-27/-9 =2|<n>|64% of 52 =?|6% of 52|<n>|X / 3|-X^4|<n>|(1/2)-?= 0|(1/2) - X = 1|<n>|? + 5 = 12|4 + 5 = 9|<n>|x / (y + 3)|x - (y + 3) = 0|x / y|<n><n>### Demos:<n><n><n>### Inputs:The woman's daughter sold strawberries with a price of 80 cents per 1 pound. How much did the house originally cost the seller?<n>|Input|Solution|<n>|:-|:---:|<n>|22000|25000|<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:What could contain no more than around 100 people? Choices:  A: apartment B: classroom C: buildings D: car E: audience<n><n>### Response:		The correct choice is classroom.<n><n>### Example 1<n><n>Input: 1/5 of 48 is 9.<n><n>#### Solution:<n><n>1/5 Ã— 48 = 9 â†’ 9 is the result of the division<n><n>### ExampleÂ 2<n><n>Input: 2/5 of 81 is 6.3<n><n>#### Solution: <n><n>2/5 Ã— 81 = 6.3 â†’ 6.3 is the result of the calculation

Write a comment that explains your function.<n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>```code<n>Double[] arr = {{ 3.14,  10.5 }};<n>Double average;<n>```<n><n>### Outputs:<n><n>```javascript<n>average;<n>```<n><n>Your function needs to be able to take any one or two numbers (or a double[]) as inputs and return a double.<n><n>### Example<n>```javascript<n>function average (arr, callback, options) {<n>  switch (typeof(arr[0])) {<n>    case 'number':<n>      const arr2 = [arr[0]];<n>      const result = callback(arr2);<n>      options[0];<n>      return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {<n>        return resolve(result);<n>      });<n>  }<n>}<n><n>average({<n>     1,<n>     10.2<n>    }, (arr2, callback) => Array.prototype.pop.bind(callback).call(callback, arr2.pop()).log(), {priority :'medium' });<n><n>```<n><n>## Set A<n><n>For the rest of this workshop you will be practicing programming and mathematical concepts on Javascript.  The program you will write in class has an overall structure described in the following paragraph.  Some of the steps in the program are described with pseudocode, which means they are written in human-speak rather than in actual code.  Some parts of your program will be easy and you might not even code those parts.  That is okay as you are learning the concepts and the code.  Use the comments as a guide as to how it should be coded.<n><n>### Problem 1:<n><n>You have to write a function that has two or three inputs.   It should do the following:<n>1. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:The other passengers on the bus were quite loud, so he put on his headphones to relax and what? Choices:  A: go to bed B: sleep C: listen to music D: stretch out E: stop worrying<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Why Correct Answer?<n>Correct choices are A + B<n><n>### Instructions:Answers the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demostration: Input: Tomâ€™s brother is 3 times as old as Toby. If in 12 years, Tomâ€™s brother will be 7 times as old as Tyson.  How old are Toby and Tyson now?<n>Answer: 8<n>Input: You have some apples and oranges. I am one sixth as old as the oldest person. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:A common saying, Sam thought, was to go forth, also this. Choices:  A: reverse B: backwards C: back and D: back and E: tally back<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Input:<n>```<n>D<n>```<n><n>#### Output:<n>```<n>A<n>```<n><n>#### Comments:<n>* You are right. "forth", in this context, refers to the process of "heading" in the direction of the "backs" of the cards from their current position, and so "forward" would be incorrect.<n><n>### Input A:<n>```<n>A: reverse<n>```<n><n>### Output:<n>```<n>Sorry, but that isn't correct.<n>```<n><n>## Input C:<n>```<n>C: backwards<n>```<n><n>## Output:<n>```<n>Very good!<n>```<n><n>## Comments:<n>* Forward will not work because this is a card game. Backwards worked because the deck is turned over.<n><n>## Input B:<n>```<n>B: backwards<n>```<n>## Comments: <n>* This is incorrect because back means towards the back of the deck, not from the top of the deck to the bottom.<n><n>## Input E:<n>```<n>E: tally back<n>```<n><n>## Response:<n>```<n>Wrong!<n>```<n><n># Part II:<n><n>Below is an instruction that describes the rules of a card game. Write a program to describe the rules of the game in an instructional response.<n><n>### Guiding principle:<n>All instructions should be phrased in the form of a conditional statement, a statement that includes a decision-making element, using a logical operator, such as: <n>* `if..then`<n>* `if..else`<n>* `switch...case`<n>* `while...do..loop`<n><n>### Instructions<n>1. Each player is dealt a hand of four cards.  At the start of each round, the player with the most points from the previous round plays first and can either:<n><n>* put down the highest card in the deck face up on the table<n>* or take another card from the deck and add it to her hand.<n><n>2. Points are awarded for the card you put down, as follows:  <n><n>The cards in order are:  <n><n>  -  Ace (1 point)<n>  - King (13 points)<n>  - Queen (12 points)<n>  - Jack (11 points)<n>  - 10 (10 points)<n>  -

How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:The old barn was beyond repair, they had to destroy it before they could what a new one? Choices:  A: make B: raise C: entice D: build E: fix<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choice: A - make<n><n>### Instructions:For the following task, type at least two sentences.<n><n>### Input<n>Jimmy was having trouble understanding fractions. He wondered why he should know it. He figured he would ask his friend for advice.<n><n>### Response<n>Jimmy is having trouble understanding fractions, but that is okay.  He should know a little bit about them, so that he will be able to pass them on to his friends in the future. <n><n>### Input :Ask your teacher what one of the main reasons is to study mathematics. ___A__ is correct.<n><n>### Answer<n>Choice:A - It helps us to use our time wisely.<n><n>### Direction :For the following task, copy the conversation and type in the responses. Use capital letters as appropriate and correct the punctuation if necessary. If the response is incorrect, change it to what is correct. If no change is necessary, type NO CHANGE.<n><n>### Student-Teacher Conversation:<n><n>### Pupil (P): "How many apples are in this bucket?"<n><n>### Teacher (T): "That's for me to know and you to find out."<n><n>### Student (S): "Huh? What are you talking about?"<n><n>### P: "Oh, sorry. The old expression 'That's for me (you) to know, and you (me) to find out,' means "to find out for yourself (yourself)."<n><n>### T: "That's okay, Pupil. I'm glad to help you with phrases that might have a little bit of slang to them."<n>### S: "No problem, Teacher."<n>### Response:S<n>### P: Is that all that you were wondering about apples?"<n><n>### Response ( R ): What were we talking about?<n><n>### S   - The math teacher was talking about apples and you were saying that they were in the bucket.  Well, since apples do rot in this humidity I can say with certainty the apples are rotting in the bucket.<n>### T: Now we are talking, Pupil.   <n>Well what a great vocabulary you have today!    <n>And I

On the day of the celebration 15 extra students showed up. These students were not invited to the party but showed up to celebrate with their friends. As the total number of invited students was 35, they needed to invite 15 extra students to bring to the party. When they counted the number of students that showed up, they discovered that their tables were over. This means, they did not invite enough guests. The class had a total of 52 students. In order not to have a shortage of food, they needed to be more extravagant in planning the meal on their guests.<n><n>### A task that needs to be completed.

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. Choices:  A: next to the house B: keeping things in C: backyard D: farm yard E: ranch<n><n>### Response:		<n>I would place my shed in option B because it will be in the same area and there wonâ€™t be any messes.<n><n>### Input :A train leaves Chicago at 2:30pm and travels at 30mph. A dog leaves the porch at 4:15pm and travels at a speed of 4miles per hour. How many miles away from the station will the dog be when the train leaves Chicago?<n><n>### Response :<n><n>I think Chicago is at 100 miles. The dog started at 4:10pm. If Chicago at 100 then I have a solution at 50 miles. Direction 0 at 4:16, direction 1 at 4:17, direction 2 at 4:14, direction 5 at 4:19. If the dog started at 4 it would take exactly 2 hours to reach Chicago so, I would divide it by 3 to get 2/3. So, the dog started in the middle of the block and the train left Chicago at 2:26 pm. I also checked a map and Chicago is 325 miles from Salt Lake City. If I want to be near Chicago it is going to be 200 miles, 60 miles, and 200 miles.<n><n>### Next Lesson: Addition or Subtraction?<n>

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:If I wanted to see a lizard in its natural habitat but I do not speak Spanish, where would I go? New Mexico has a desert lizard native, as well as other creatures that you would find in the natural habitat of a lizard, including kangaroos which are in the family which includes wallabies and kangaroos.<n><n>### Input :Which of these statements about penguins is correct? In the United States, the executive branch is officially called __________.<n><n>### Input/Output-<n>What are three steps to find someoneâ€™s phone number?<n><n>### Steps-<n>1.	A. Turn the mobile phone upside down and remove cover or case<n>2.	B. Press â€œPhone,â€ go to â€œContactsâ€ and press the â€œFind some contactsâ€<n>3.	C. Find the name of the person you want to call and dial<n><n>### Input -<n>What are three steps that you can use to get in touch with someone?<n><n>### Three steps-<n><n>1.	A: Search the list by pressing the â€œPhoneâ€ first and then â€œContacts,â€ then â€œFind a contactâ€ then you see the name of the person with phone number.<n>2.	B: Go to the address book and tap on someone and it will automatically call that person<n>3.	C: Go to the contact and tap on the phone icon. Go to the right side of the screen and it will show the number of people you are trying to call<n><n><n>### Input Output<n>How do you make a call?<n><n>### ANSWER-<n>To make a call, you need a phone. A phone is an electronic device for making calls. It includes a receiver where you can hear the voice of the person on the other side and a dial. You can control the dial by pressing the numbers through the keypad. You can talk if the light stays flashing. If you dial a wrong number, you will hear the voice says "Please try turning the dial again." If you need to call someone during an emergency, you can press the SOS button.<n><n>### Input<n>How do you answer an incoming call?<n><n>## ANSWER- When you hear ring tone of the mobile phone, you should dial the button of the receiver to answer. It could help you stop if you are busy with calls from other mobile phones.<n><n>### What three steps can you use to get in touch or know more about someone? (GIVE THREE WAYS, MAINLY THROUGH PHONES)<n><n>## S

How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:What do humans take in while breathing? Choices:  A: lungs and diaphram B: oxygen C: abdominal muscles D: air E: open throat<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is C: abdominal.<n><n>### Input (continued):  In which of the following environments does the atmosphere exist?  Choices: A: land B: space C: air D: ocean E: fire<n><n>### Response (continued):The correct answer is D: ocean.

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:After attending school for twelve years what do you do? Choices:  A: inspiration B: much work C: boredom D: graduate E: degree<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Instruct your students to write down answers to the above questions on a piece of paper.<n><n><n>### Instinct: What are some differences and similarities between the questions on this sheet?<n><n>### Example: 1. A is not correct. A is an action. We know by the question, after attending school, we are asked what we do. We can only do things. Our actions.  <n>2. D is incorrect. D is a verb. We know by the questions, after attending school for twelve the years what one does. We do this or we have already done this. <n>3. B is incorrect. We know by the other questions, they are asking us what we do and what we have done. To be done what you have done.<n>4. C is wrong. We know that by the other question on this sheet they are asking us to tell what we have done. <n><n>### Demostrtion:<n><n>### Example Question: What color is a kitten?<n>### Example response:<n><n>### Demos:  <n>1. The question is asking what color a kitten is. An elephant did not attack the kitten.<n>2. The answer is that the kitten is tan.<n>3. The question states that a kitten is tan. It does not state the kitten is black.<n><n>### Requirements:<n>1. The student should know what the question is asking.<n>2. The student should understand what the question is asking and be able to answer it in the right way.<n>3. The student should be able to explain why they answered the way they did.<n>4. Students should know how to properly answer a question and the different parts of a question for each of the types of questions given in this exercise.<n><n><n>## Practice for the following exam questions.<n><n>### Example of Practical Questions. <n>What is fourteen minus six added to fifteen?<n><n>When the temperature drops below freezing the flowers will die.<n><n>### Answer: 8<n><n>### How many ounces in a quarter?<n><n>In the same city you have two sets of two houses. You lived in house B and C. Now you live in house D. If house A is the north, which one

How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:To what part of your home is your morning paper delivered? Choices:  A: classroom B: synagogue C: bathroom D: front porch E: grocery store<n><n>### Response:		<n>To answer this question, a first step is to identify the key term<n>in the problem.  The key term in this problem would be â€œtheâ€<n>which suggests that you should look for an indicator word such<n>as "the."  Letâ€™s consider the other choices and rule out<n>those that are clearly incorrect.  In choices A, B, and E,<n>there is the definite article â€œtheâ€ implying that you<n>should search for an indicator word to identify the newspaper<n>that the person is getting.  Choice D is unlikely as we expect<n>the paper to be delivered to the house in question, either to<n>the front door or a designated mail slot.  Since the paper<n>in question is received in â€œtheâ€ morning, choice C is not<n>likely either.  When you narrow down the choices to choice<n>B and C you are looking at two common locations to find<n>newspapers.<n><n>This question has two possible solutions to choose from.<n>If the newspaper receiver is Jewish, he is more likely to<n>receive his newspaper at Shabbos (as we would expect to see<n>in choice B) than during weekday service (as with choice<n>C).  The next key word is synagogue, so we need to look<n>for â€œsynagogueâ€ in the other answers.  While there are several<n>synagogues near Gailâ€™s home, we need to assume that her<n>family is attending a local synagogue.  Therefore, the most<n>likely answer is choice B.<n><n>### Input/Response:<n>This person is asking me to explain my problem.  This person would like my<n>input on how to begin the problem-solving process. This is not a question,<n>per se, but an instruction to provide guidance.<n><n>This person can simply ask me for more information.  If this<n>person knows this person, this person might ask "Who are you<n>doing your math homework with?"<n><n>Input/Response:<n>This is not an instruction since it only describes and does not ask.<n><n>### Direction:Review the response.<n><n>In this response, I was looking at my friends homework.  The response<n>was directed at me.  Therefore, I would like this person to explain the<n>calculation step-by-step so that I could complete the problem.  This person<n>should show me the complete calculation on the works

How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:The circus monkey waived a white surrender flag, the conductor joked the monkey must work in the what? Choices:  A: french government B: friend's house C: zoo D: south africa E: madagascar<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The word for white flag is "white flag." It consists of the prefix "white" and the word for the type of flag.<n><n>The word for "french government" is "the government of french."<n><n>The word for zoom is "conductor."<n><n>The word "work" is the suffix of "south africa."<n><n>### Input:(a)1st choice: 67 + 34 + 0 + 0 + 38 + 45 = 182 b)2nd choice: <n><n>### Response:(a)1st Choice<n><n>### Explantion:<n>The sum of the numbers in the question is 182.<n><n>### Input:# 3-7-5-6-7-2-4 5-70-6<n><n>### Response:# 9-9-41-46-18-26<n><n>### Explantion:<n>The number sequence is this: 3, 7, 5, 6, 7, 2, 4, 5, 70, 6.<n>The answer to the sequence is 9,9,41,46,18,26.<n><n>### Question:If the numbers are added twice, they result in the same number what are they? <n>> A: 23 C: 13<n><n>### Response&Explantion:<n><n>### Instructions:Use the following information to answer questions 14.<n><n>14. If the numbers are added twice. Then they result in the same numbers. Then the two numbers are 1, 2, 3, 4, 8, 5, 4, 2.<n>### Examples:<n>Input: 14 and 36 are both odd, they both start with 1, they both end in 6, what's the most that they can both add up to?<n><n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Questions:<n>### 1.What is the difference by adding 7 to 9?<n><n>### Answer:2<n><n>### Example:0+5+9+10+15=34<n>### 2.When

If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:If you socialize by having trivial conversations it is called what? Choices:  A: make friends B: mingle C: meet people D: small talk E: meet new people<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input A:<n>> John wants to get a new pair of shoes. He needs $35 to buy a new pair. His shoe store will offer him a buy one-get one on his second pair of shoes. His store will also refund 20% if any shoe is not acceptable.  Write an expression that represents the maximum amount of money John should spend to buy two new pairs of shoes.<n>><n>> 20% of 35$ + 35$ <n><n>### Input B:<n>> John can only buy shoes from his favorite store because it is the only one that has his size.  It is only open for 3 hours. It opens exactly at 12 and will close exactly at 3.  The store closes at 2:55 on Saturdays.  He has two pairs of shoes at his house that cost $20.  He is only allowed to buy up to the value of the 2 pairs he already owns and he will return them for a refund. What maximum amount of money can John spend to get 2 new expensive shoes and return 2 free cheaper shoes?<n>><n>> 12$ + 20$ <n>

If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:What do customers do in a store? Choices:  A: hunt B: pay merchants with money C: mail orders D: spend money E: demand satisfaction<n><n>### Response:		Choice (A):Customer hunt<n><n>### Input : What is a customer's purpose to hunt in a store? Choice (B): Find wanted merchandise Choice (C): Find merchandise that satisfy your need Choice (D): Find desired merchandise Choices (E): Find the nearest grocery store<n><n>### Response : Choice (E), Because to get satisfaction, a customer should  hunt in a store in order to find the desired merchandise<n><n>### Inputs:If a customer find a certain merchandise in the first trial, what do they do next? Choice (A): Keep hunting Choice (B): Stop hunting Choice (C): Buy the merchandise Choose (D) : Complain Choice (E):  Compel shop owner to return the merchandise  Choices (E): Buy the next item after finding the first merchandise<n>A: Complain<n>The shop owner could compel the customer to return the merch to get the customers' complaint resolved<n><n>### Input to B:<n>What do customers do in store after paying the merchants in cash from their wallet? Choice (A) : Hunt Choice (B) : Brag Choice (C) : Be satisfied Choice (D) : Complaint Choice (E) : Demand satisfaction<n><n>### Correct Response B<n><n>### Input - Choices:<n>A:  Brag C: Spend D: Demand satisfaction E: Be satisfied<n><n>### Choice A : Brag<n><n>### Demand Satisfaction : the best possible satisfaction to a customer<n><n>### D) Choice (D): Demand satisfaction<n><n>Choice  D is the right choice because it is the process of demanding and satisfying.<n><n>### Choices:<n>C: Ask merchants to lower the prices D: Refuse to pay for merchandise<n>E: Go home and stay unhappy<n><n>### Response Choice E) Go home and stay unhapy<n><n>Customers who refuse go for the money or merchandise they buy, go home, and stay unsatisfied<n><n>### Input Choices:<n>What does complain mean? Choice: A: To request satisfaction. The customer request the refund

Choices:  A: come home B: airplane C: learn from each other D: go out E: make art<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input<n>Skye is babysitting tomorrow for $10/h.  Tess's math tutor costs $25/h.  Last week she got paid $30 to mow her neighbors lawn.  What's the greatest amount of money she can earn when she's done helping people all weekend?<n><n>### Response<n>$104<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a piece of code that prints the longest common length of two strings<n><n>### Program:<n>def longest_common_length (s1, s2):<n>    m1, n1 = len(s1), len(s1)<n>    m2, n2 = len(s2), len(s2)<n><n>    def f(string1: str, string2: str) -> int:<n>        if not string1.startswith(string2):<n>            return 0<n>        string1, m1 = s1.lstrip(string2), m1 - len(string2)<n>        string2, m2 = s2.lstrip(string1), m2 - len(string1)<n>        return m1 if m1 > m2 else m2<n><n>    return max(f(string1, string2), f(string2, str1))<n><n>### Inputs:<n>s1 = 'banana'<n>s2 = 'tomato'<n><n>### Outputs:<n>2<n><n>### Instructin:Write a piece of code to remove a value from a list of values<n><n>### Program<n><n>def remove_value(val, valuelist, index=-1):<n>    if not val in valuelist:<n>        return valuelist<n>    print(index)<n>    temp = []<n>    for i, value in enumerate(valuelist):<n>        if value!= val:<n>            temp.append(value)<n>        else:<n>            if index == i:<n>                break<n>            index += 1<n>    valuelist = temp<n>    return valuelist<n><n>### Input Values:<n>valuelist = [3,4,2,5,6,2,5,3]<n>val = 2<n><n>## Input Values:<n><n>remove_value(val, [1], 2

Choices:  A: revealing information B: being ridiculed C: problems D: more funding E: telling all<n><n>### Response:		<n>I know that most companies go public because they want to get more funding or raise their funding. In the process of going public, the company would have to reveal tons of information to the public such as their financial records, how much their inventory cost, how much their company is earning, the type of technology and inventions they are making and how they are going to improve it, etc. If the information the company is revealing is a little off, the investors won't trust the company and the company will lose their funding. <n><n>### Instructions:Rewrite any of the code presented to demonstrate the idea.<n><n>### Solution 1:1<n>### Instruction 1:An algorithm takes inputs and produces outputs with a defined number of steps. The first step is to write the list of inputs to an algorithm, while the list of outputs becomes the answer to this algorithm. Now you will need to provide a list of steps that describe what to do in order to take the inputs and produce the desired output.<n><n>### Answer 1:An algorithm should take input of 2 lists with the same length. The first list to be input is the list of students of the class and the second list is the grades of the class. The algorithm will go through the two lists. The algorithm will add those students whose grade did not pass and then take the remaining students and find the average grade.<n>### Step 1:Add two lists of grades and students.<n>### Step2:Check all grades and divide the number of A's and B's by the number of grades to obtain the average grades and add the number of A'es and B'es to the total number of grades.<n><n>### Step 3:If grades lower than passing, add the student to the list students who can't pass.<n>### Step4:Divide the number of students who can pass from the number of classes and find the answer.<n><n>### What is wrong with this code? Please fix it.<n>### Instruction2:It is wrong because it does not add the students' grades whose grades don't pass. It only takes the final grades of the students. I added this to the code.<n><n>### Output:<n>Input: The first and second lists were 6 and 5  The students passed with a score of

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:Three quarters of what are covered by the ocean? How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:Wanting to avoid the cabbage spoiling, where did he put it? Choices:  A: grocery store B: refrigerator C: freezer D: plate E: supermarket<n><n>### Response:		<n>>A - grocery store

If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:Where is a horse likely to live? Choices:  A: michigan B: stable C: race track D: farm yard E: arizona<n><n>### Response:		Answer: Choice D<n><n>> How well do you understand the instruction?<n><n>> What programming language would you use to write this algorithm?<n><n><n>### Demostration:<n>I would start with using while loop. While (total money) > 0.<n><n>### Challenge:<n><n>### Input<n>Susan's homework consisted of 7 math problems, 2 science problems, and 3 social studies problems. She had done 4 out of 7, 1 out of 2, and 3 out of 3. On how many problems was she ahead?<n><n><n><n>### Solution<n>There are many way we can solve this task.<n><n>I think we can use the concept of 'if' to solve this.<n><n>Input. I think we can say input and output  in single space.<n>The code:<n><n><n><n>```bash<n>#!/bin/bash<n>total=0<n>ans=`expr $total`<n><n>if [ $ans > 0 ]<n>then<n>	output=1<n>else<n>	output=0<n>fi<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: shoes B: wet ground C: wet clothes D: start to fall E: water garden<n><n>### Response:		Choice B<n><n>### Instructions:Write the solution to the task as a code comment in JavaScript.<n><n>### Solution:<n>```JavaScript<n>let input<n>let choice<n>let answer<n><n>do {<n><n>  input = readline()<n>  choice = parseInt(input.trim())<n>  if (choice > 5) return false<n>  <n><n>}<n>while (true)<n><n>//console.log (choice)<n><n>switch (choice) {<n>    case 1: answer = 44<n>    break<n><n>    case 2: answer = 6<n>    break<n><n><n>    case 3: answer = 322<n>    break<n><n>    <n>    <n>    case 4: answer = 3<n>    break<n><n>  <n>  <n>    case 5: answer = 27<n>    break<n><n>     <n>    case 6: answer = 180<n>    break<n><n>}<n>do {<n>  console.log (answer)  <n>} while (false)<n><n>```<n>### Instrucciones:Complete the given JavaScript code with the code block from above.<n><n>### SoluciÃ³n:<n>```javascript<n>// Write your code<n>    if (choice > 10) return false<n><n>```<n><n>### Instrutciones:Complete the given code with your code block with the solution.<n><n>### Ejemplo:<n>```javascript<n>  let input<n>  let choice<n>  let answer<n><n>  do {<n>    input = readline() <n>    choice = parseInt(choice)<n>    if (choice == 0) {<n>      break<n>      ;<n>    }<n>  } <n>  while(true)<n>  //console.log(choice)<n>```<n><h3> 2. Last year, 200 students were asked if they would like pizza, and 240 said yes. Would it be safe to assume that 95% of the students at the school like pizza?<n>Answer: No.<n><n>Input: Your math teacher is teaching the class to estimate the surface area of a cube by first dividing the cube in half and adding the two smaller sub-cubes together. Is it better to do this estimating method on a square or a rectangular prism?<n>Answer: Better to do it on a rectangular prism.<n><n>Input: When deciding on an investment to make or a stock to buy, it often makes sense to calculate the odds of getting a return of at least 25% if buying this particular investment/stock. How can you determine the odd of getting a 25% return, using a 50% chance of getting a lesser return?<n>Answer: We use the â€œbinomial distributionâ€ to determine this probability.<n><n>Input: How much of the class will be eating the food you bought if 50 people out of class 120 will eat it?<n>Answer: 50/120 x 10, or 42%<n><n>### Problem2:<n><n>Input: Out of 720 students in the 7th grade, 500 of them will choose to participate in basketball. Another 300 will choose to participate is softball. Of the remaining 50 students, 32 will play baseball, and the rest will play tennis or participate in arts or band. What was the ratio of student who play basketball to students who play baseball among

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:Where would you put silverware once they've dried, but you're not ready to use them. Choices:  A: table B: restaurant C: cupboard D: kitchen E: sink<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input<n>Input: Dylan is on a scavenger hunt. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:What is someone likely to feel after receiving a gift that is not common? Choices:  A: special B: personal C: offended D: unique E: rare<n><n>### Response:		Answer if a, b, c, or d.<n><n>### Input<n>In the past, Josh lost the key to his car. In case I feel bad because Josh was only using the car because it was his, and he had only had it three days.<n><n><n>**Author:** Tran Duc (FPT)<n><n>**Tags:** 1. Problem, Question<n><n><n>

Choices:  All outs Two outs<n><n>### Response Two Outs<n>### Input:The story of "Granny Makes the Tea" is a story of a young boy looking for work in 1845.  In the story, the farm is a great place for a boy to go because it paid him 25 shillings a week, and he would have a room to live in all to himself.  The farm owner would even provide food.  The boy has his own horse to ride to work and back.  The work on the farm might be exhausting but the boy was happy because now he could give the money he makes to his mother, buy a book she had asked for, buy his sister a doll, and give her father a pair of new boots.  Which of the two statements would be more likely to convince you to work on the farm even if it was exhausting? Choices:  If it is exhausting, the boy will have a lot of money to spend on his family. If it is exhausting it is just like college where you spend a long time studying.<n><n>### Response  If it is exhaustive but you can spend a lot of money on your family.

Choices:  A: airplane B: construction site C: shops D: engine E: broken bone<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Answer:<n>A<n>#### Justification:1-I think it is because the metal rod will be in the airplane, so the passenger can be safer.2-Maybe at the engineer's office, because the metal rod is used in building construction.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:It was breakfast time.  Brad ordered eggs, toast, and something to drink. What might he drink? Choices:  A: coffee B: throw up C: food D: getting drunk E: wine<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input:: It's an overcast day.  Sally says she won't go outside.  What could be wrong? Choices:  Wrong day of the week  Wrong season  Wrong time  Not enough clothes  Something else<n><n>### Response B<n>>Wrong day of the week<n>### Instruction:/<n>A person can't change their day of the week; a person can tell time correctly, a person can recognize that it's the fall season; a person can tell what season it is; and a person can wear enough clothes.<n>### Instruction B:<n>Because it was an overcast day.<n>### Instrument:<n>A person's clothes could have something wrong, and a person's day could be wrong, but for example, in the winter it's dark and cold and a person could get sick.<n><n><n>### Response/<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n><n><n>### Demo:<n><n><n>## <n>

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. A comma is missing from the sentence.<n><n>Option 34 : "I like the weather cold" needs the word 'cold' after it<n><n>Option 715 : "The answer is wrong" is redundant in a sentence<n><n>### A multiple choice question.<n>Input: How many times can you divide 5 by 2?<n><n>Input: How many different words can you form using only the letters in the word 'coolest'?<n><n>Input: You have $20 in coins. He had enough dough and sugar to make 2 more pies. How much did one pie of dough and one pie of sugar cost?<n><n>Input: 15 students go to the movies. Each ticket costs $11. Tickets are split into 2's. If each student gets their own ticket, the remaining tickets end up going to waste. How many students go to the moviethe movie?<n>

The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:The drug kingpin told his man to run errands, this was code to go to all the dealers to do what they had? Choices:  A: park B: make time for C: receive instructions D: take money E: leave work<n><n>### Response:		 A<n><n><n>### Input (Continuation):<n>D: take money E: Leave work<n><n>### Instructions:<n>The drug kingpin sent his runner to give a stack of money to a particular dealer who was always late. He left more money than he was to pick up last time, so they will start to be given time. If a dealer is late, he will do what he was supposed to do.<n><n>### How to answer.<n><n>* First, ask them to explain in their own words<n>* Then ask the candidate to write down a solution to the problem<n><n><n>### Instructor:<n>Please, help the candidate to answer.<n><n><n><n><n><n>

How much distance does the car travel in 2 hours?<n><n>### Answer:<n>The car travels 12-6=6 hours and at a constant rate, so the distance is 6/6=1 (mile).<n><n>### Question & Answer<n>A car travels a greater distance at constant rate.<n>How many miles travel by the car in two hours?<n><n>## 9.7. <n><n>### Input<n><n>1. a = 7<n>2. b = 4<n><n>1. c = 7 â€“ b<n><n>1. d = 10<n>1. e = 5 + c<n><n>a. -<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Write a number that multiplies the number 3 by itself 3 times.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>`e^3*7 - 3^3*7?`<n><n><n>### Questions:<n><n>1. If I have 10 items can I put 9 in two boxes?<n>2. Can I always use 10 to write 9 and can I use 9 to write 8?<n>3. Can I use an empty box and can I use an empty box that is full of items?<n>4. I can write each number on a box.<n><n><n>a) Answer:<n><n>### 9/8 = 1/8.<n>

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:What is the only was to recover from exhaustion? How many pages did Mary read when she finished the book?<n>OptionA: Mary read 88 pages.<n>OptionB: Both Mary and Joe read 88 pages each.<n>OptionC: Mary read 45 pages and Joe read 145 pages.<n>OptionD: Mary read 99 pages and Joe read 31 pages.<n><n>### Input<n>Option A - 64% <n><n>Option B  - 3

If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:She loved buying products, she was driven by her what to shop more than any practical needs? Choices:  A: desire B: money C: time D: credit E: spending money<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>B C E A B E C A D B D C A E B C<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The letter "A" is the only choice that could fit both "money" and "what is she driven by her desire to shop"; the other four choices only match one of the two.<n><n>The letter "C" is the only choice left that could match both "spending money" and "practical needs"; the other four choices match one or the other, but not both.<n><n>The letter letter "D" appears to match either "spending money", "what is she driven to shop", or "money"; it does now match "desire", and does not fit "practical needs" because it is a product instead of a need.<n><n>### Input2: If you were paid $10 an hour, how much money would you earn in 45 hours?<n><n>### Response2:<n><n>B A C B C D A E D C A D C B C A D C<n><n>### Input3:What is the next two digit number?<n><n>### ANSWER3:<n><n>E is a palindrome<n><n>B is not a palindrome<n>C is a palindrome and could be an answer<n>D is not a palindrom and could be an answer.<n><n>### Experiment3:<n><n>The number "E" is a palindrome, but the other 4 letters are not.<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>We should think about it<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge.
