If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:What group of musicians will include someone playing the cello? Choices:  A: ocean B: symphony C: band D: music store E: music shop<n><n>### Response:		<n>Let's suppose there is a man and woman who are a team of musician and man play cello. The band, symphony and music store are not applicable because they are not a musician group.<n><n>Based on the question, we know who will include who and the group of musicians will consist of one man and one woman.<n><n>### Input. What animal is missing?<n><n>### Response.<n>I will not choose the answer as the answer is inappropriate in the instruction<n><n>Input: A man has five pairs of shoes, each pair has leather soles. He is left with 5 pairs.<n><n>### Response<n>Solution:<n>1.		To get 4 pair of shoes, he should have all pairs<n>2.		To get two and two extra of that same pair of shoes<n>3.		To get one and 2 extra of that same pair shoes<n>4.		To get three and one extra pair of shoes<n>5.		To get only 2 extra of that pair shoes.<n><n><n>### Input : What number is not in this group?<n><n>### Solution - Response.<n><n>### Solution:<n>The option in which 3 does not go with 2 and -, -5 are not numbers.<n><n>### Correct Answer: The answer must either be 3, 5, or 9.<n>### Solution : 3 is not in the group.<n><n>### Correction:<n>The above answer is correct because the option which does not go with 3, 5 and -, -5 is 6.

If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:She was sick and staying in bed the day of the event, unfortunately this meant she was what? Choices:  A: resting B: sleep more C: bed sores D: missing out E: comfort<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Instructions:<n>### Output:<n><n>### Demos:<n><n>### Input Example:<n>She was missing out on the event<n><n>### Expected Output:<n>She was sleeping more<n><n>### Output Example:<n>He was missing out on the party<n><n>### Input Ex:  She was missing out on the even<n><n>Output:  She was missing the day<n><n>### Input : She was sleeping at home<n><n>Output: She stayed at home<n><n>### Input :- She slept at home on the day of the event<n><n>Output : She was at home<n><n>Output : She stayed at home<n>

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:What could prevent someone from buying chistmas presents? Choices:  A: happiness B: lack of money C: stress D: relief E: exhiliration<n><n>### Response:		 <n>I think Gail's problems were happiness and money. In the first question, she had more than enough money to buy presents for the entire list she presented, but she still didn't buy anything because she was unhappy about an ex-boyfriend. In the problem she had money but was still unhappy because she had to share the presents with her best friend. This would leave her in a predicament to have to buy even more. Therefore, happiness and money are the problems in the examples.<n><n>### The Answer:  <n>A: B: C: D: E:<n><n>### Input Choices:<n><n>### Response Choices:<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: kick the bucket B: mortal C: dead D: can die E: dying<n><n>### Response:		<n>`C:`<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Another word of immortality is *mortal*.<n><n>### Input Two<n><n>### Input : Two cars 148 miles away from a garage are 90 miles away from each other. One of the drivers has a tire that's flat. What is the fastest possible way to get them to the garage where they can get a new tire? Choices:  Choose from the drop-down menu?A: Traveling at 45 MPH on the highway, driving in a straight lineB: Traveling at  55 MPH, driving in a straight-lineC: Traveling at **51** MPH in an uninterrupted line (no stops for gas or food)D: Traveling at more than 60 MPH in a straight line.<n><n>### Response :<n>`A:`<n><n>The straight line distance from each of their current positions is 162 - halfway, and halfway and the garage is 162 miles.<n><n>The shortest distance between two points, in a line, is as the crow flies. Thus their shortest route would be straight-line.<n><n><n>### Input Three<n>### Input : The number 6, multiplied by 3, equals how many times? When you have 1 baked potato and you divide them even, the last potato is <n><n>a. two<n>b. eight<n>c. none<n>d. one<n>e. zero<n>Answer: 2.<n>If two baked potatoes are divided evenly, 2 apples will be left. If one baked potato is divided evenly, the remainder is 1/2 of itself. So, when dividing one baked potato in half, we get half and we get half the baked potato left.<n>

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:Where must one wear a white shoe? Choices:  A: wedding B: tennis C: closet D: left foot E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>A) Tennis<n><n>### Reasons:<n>A. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:When would you be able to see your reflection in a piece of wood? How many minutes per day do you spend doing the following?<n>  - Eating<n>  - Spending time with friends and family<n>  - Playing sports<n>  - Doing housework<n>  - Watching TV<n>  - Helping out around the house<n>  - Studying<n>  - On a computer<n>  - Going to school<n>  - On the phone<n>#### 2.  How many hours of sleep out of 15 you get per day?<n><n>### Response<n><n>##### Total number of minutes per day spent doing listed activities<n>```<n>+-----+-----+-----+-------+-----+-----+----<n>|Eating|Friends|Sports|Houswork|TV| Helping|<n>|    |       |      |        |    |        |<n>+-----+---- |      +---- |-------+---- |-------+--<n>	|+-------------- +--------------|--------------|<n>    | 42              24    3    2     232    2   23   				<n>--------------------+----------<n> | 1              0		  4<n>----------------------+------<n>Total Minutes Per Day   66<n>```<n><n>##### Total hours of sleep per day<n>```<n>+-------+-----+-------+-------+----<n>|Sleep |   TV |  Radio | Computer|<n>+-------+---- |-----+-------+---- |<n>|+------------|--------------|---------|<n> |  12.5     | 3.25     | 2.75      | 6<n>--------------------+------+-----+---<n>| 5.25      | 1       | 1      | 8<n>----------------------+--	<n>Total Hours of Day   |5<n><n> ```<n> ####Total Number of minutes per day = 66<n> ####Total Hours of day =5<n> ####Total minutes of sleep per day =12.5<n><n>#Code<n><n>### Code your answer. <n><n>### Code Description:<n>Input: A set of cards is to be arranged around a table so that no two adjacent cards of the same suit have a lower number than another adjacent card of the same suit. His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. In this case you could say the answer is 7 because 7 is the sum of 2 +4 +6.<n><n>Input: The sum if the first and all of the second numbers in sequence. In this case you can say the answer is 6.<n><n>Answer: FirstNumber = 2<n><n>For i = 1 to number of second numbers<n><n>  i = i + FirstNumber<n><n>Output: i<n><n><n>If(i <= 2)<n>    Answer = FirstNumber + i<n><n>Else<n>    Answer = FirstNeuron + (11 + LastNumber + (number of last numbers)) + (-1)<n><n><n>### Input & Response:<n>Write a program that prints all the strings that can be formed in a given string using certain characters. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. There was a shortage of 6 workers, so someone had to remain behind. How did the chief of the village convince this group of explorers to stay? <n><n>> The chief of the village was very rich, he offered them the same job as the 6 they left behind.<n><n>### Response<n><n>```<n>Answer:<n>        The chief of the village knew their was a group of explore, so he had a plan. He knew that he couldn't change his people because of what he does so he asked to give him the 6 explorers. The explorer chief talked to his natives and said that he would bring the same job for his people like him. That made the chief angry and the explorer chief told him to change the job of his people to the same job as the job his people do. The chief didn't answer anything. But when the chief saw that they were getting things he said to the explorer chief that his people have already done the job. After a minute he understood that the explorer chief was right. That is the reason why the explorer chief convinced the chief to stay. That was the reason.<n>```<n><n><n>### Question2:<n><n>What did the chief do to show they accepted the explorer's proposition?<n><n>> The chief had a plan that the same job should make his people happy. <n><n>### Response <n>```<n>Answer:  <n>        The chief knew the 50 natives have the same plan as they. They knew that they were rich and they gave them a job to give their people the same. <n><n>```<n><n>### Challenge:<n><n>What should the explorer chief do for the next group of explorers?<n><n>> The explorer chief should convince to the next group of explores that if have the need of natives they can call them and they should give them the job. Choices:  A: practice B: dexterity C: idle time D: knowledge of music E: conductor<n><n>### Response:		Option A<n>  ### Reasoning: Practice refers to an activity where you can learn a skill while idle time refers to not doing anything.<n>  <n>### Input:Your boss is an efficient person.<n><n>### Choices<n>A: not organized<n>B: not effective<n>C: creative<n>D: friendly<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Reasoning: Your boss would be defined as a not so creative individual. Being creative would not make a boss efficient (a) or effective (b). Furthermore, friendliness would only be considered if the individual had a social position different from your boss's (d). Thus, the best option remains is option (c).<n><n>### Input : When you have an extra $10, how do you feel about getting dessert? Choices: A: You don't eat it. B: Delicious! C: You don't care. D: You prefer not to go out for dinner. E: A little. F: You like it almost always.<n><n>### Response :<n><n>### Reasons :<n><n>### Choice (a) : $10 is not much for getting a dessert. If you do get a dessert, it can't be considered extra because it was actually paid for.<n><n>### choice (c) : When money in not an issue, I want to buy dessert. I don't really care about not getting a dessert when I'm paying for it.<n><n>### Option (e) : I don't eat dessert when I've paid for it because it's my money and not free.<n><n>However, if I have not eaten dessert on a given day and I don't really like dessert, I don't really mind paying for it. If I'm buying for myself a dessert on my own account, I would say choice (e)<n><n>

"Of course I can," Jill responded. "You've done it before, Jill." "What do you mean?" Roddy asked. "It's your job. You've done it for us before. It would be selfish if you refused. I trust you to do a good job. I don't want you to feel as if your services aren't appreciated. You're so good at making a party fun," Jill replied. "Thank you," Roddy said. "I can do it. Do you want to help me, Jill?" "I'd love to," Jill said.  What did Roddy mean that Jill would be selfish if she refused? A: Jill would have been selfish if she refused to help Roddy do things for this year's winter dance. B: It would have been selfish for Jill to take help from Roddy to arrange things for the winter dance. Choices:  A: jigsaw puzzle B: chess game C: puzzle box D: jigsaw puzzel puxxle E: puxxle<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer is<n><n>A: jigsaw puzz<n><n>When you look at the entire phrase it is saying "What is made out of one piece" if you had to guess it would be a jigsaw or puzzle as that is what it says. One piece so A is the only thing that could be a puzzle or jigsaw so it would be A but A does not have to mean puzz or jigsaw in all cases. Another example is a pencil and it has one piece but it looks like a pencil.<n><n>### Input :A: a sponge E: a sock B: a paper towel sheet C: a shirt D: a T-shirt<n>There are many different things that can be called a blanket including a quilt, afghan, or comforter. The blanket is a cover or wrap that is used by humans to protect them from sleeping in cold temperatures and is more complex and multifunctional than a sheet used as a bed covering.<n><n>### Response : The correct answer is :D: a T-shirts<n><n>### Description :<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:Where would you put a dictionary while you're using it? Choices:  A: library B: study area C: table D: classroom E: shelf<n><n>### Response:		<n>**Choose one**<n><n>*   A<n><n>*   B<n><n>*   C<n><n>*   D<n><n>*   E<n><n>*   Unknown else<n><n>### Input - A: Which one of these shapes has equal sides?<n><n>*   An oval<n>*   An elbow<n>*   An octagon<n>*   A rhombus<n>*   A rectangle<n><n>*   A circle is shaped by a continuous line drawn so that there are no gaps. This is equal to having sides that are equal.<n>*   The oval doesn't.<n>*   An elongated rectangle with rounded ends. The lines are not equal.<n>*   An octagonal shape has eight sides which are equal in length.<n>*   A rhumbell does not have equal lengths along its sides.<n>*   A rectangle has four equal sides.<n><n>### Input<n><n>How many times do you have to flip this flip-flop to wear it upside down?<n><n>*   A flip-flop has two flaps, so it has two sides.<n>*   When you flip it, one side goes and one stays, so you end up wearing it right way down.<n>*   It takes twice as long on the second and third flips.<n>*   It's never worn upside down, so the answer is unknown.<n>*   There are only two sides, so it takes infinite flips.<n><n>### Output<n><n>A flip-flop only has two sides, so it doesn't matter which way they are oriented.<n><n>### Response<n><n>**Choose one and only one**<n><n>*  There are only two flaps, so its only two sides.<n>*  A flip-fop has two sides only, so it's infinite.<n>*  It should take three flips the first time to wear it upside-down.<n><n>### Problem Definition<n><n>The flip-flop in the picture above is made of two sides. <n><n>Flip it once and it is still a flip-flop. To flip it upside-down, you have to flip it twice.<n><n>### Alternative Answer<n><n>There are only two sides. So if you flip it one time, it stays the same. <n>

Choices:  A: arrogate B: retain C: embrace D: smile E: engage<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Context:<n>We had a problem when trying to execute the next part.<n><n>### Input for Execution Phase<n>* Bill is the name of the student who left the battle in the previous part. The battle is mentioned in the previous part.<n>* What the student did is the question asked in the previous part and is related to the previous part.<n><n>## Execution:<n><n>* In case the above is unreadable, you can download the image and view it locally to inspect the problem: [Download Image](https://assets.codecademy.com/uploads/users/227/files/9380-447033/447034.png?token=Bq1D9C-F8VjNj4sKdT-A)<n><n># Solution<n><n>* This part needs some explanation.<n>  * The execution will fail because the name of the student was empty after being written to the database.  It means that the variable "student" was blank.  This causes PHP to throw an error which fails the execution.<n>  * The solution to this is to check that the variable that we are about to write to the input is not empty. The code to do this is ```if (!empty($student))`<n><n># Code <n><n>```php<n>// Instructions: Add the following code to execute the given task.<n>// Instructions should reference the task title (e.g. Answer the fo...<n>if (!empty($student)) {<n>  // Write the given code below.<n>  $student. $answer = false;<n>}<n>```<n><n><n>#

How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:Where could you find a fox hunting when not in a forest? Choices:  A: open meadow B: arctic tundra C: beach D: great outdoors E: england<n><n>### Response:		A: This is correct. The fox hunting will be found in an open meadow.

It was a what? Choices:  A: countryside B: anthology C: dull read D: state park E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		A. Cut off the 3rd word of the sentence (â€œIt was a whatâ€) to get â€œIt was aâ€ Then, pick the correct answer.<n><n>### Inputâ€A: When I went to the beach, I played on the dunes and I found a seashell.  Iâ€™ve been collecting seashells for eight years, so it was an old shell.  A: Choice: A: B: B. It was a what?<n><n>### Response B is correct.<n><n>### Output: The word â€œwhatâ€ is the key to understanding whether it is something a person does or something a place has.<n>>**Hint**: When the word â€œwhatâ€ is before the verb, the sentence is describing a person. When â€œwhatâ€ is after the verb, the sentence describes a place.<n><n>### Task:<n>- Write a sentence that describes the task that you will perform and then perform the task by demonstrating it to a partner.<n><n>### Expected Response:What is the rule to determine whether a word is a who or a what? What happens to the word when it is moved to the other side of the verb?<n>

If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:If you have trouble beginning work you're suffering from what? Choices:  A: sitting down B: excitement C: tiredness D: progress E: procrastination<n><n>### Response:		Choice A:<n>  A: sitting down<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input:If you have trouble getting out of bed you were not the only person to suffer from it. You were not suffering from excitement either or you would have gotten right out of bed. If you were not suffering from either sitting down or procrastination then you were not sitting down. If you were not sitting down and not suffering from getting out of bed, then you were suffering from excitement.<n><n>Input: A: sitting down<n>Answer:C: tiredness<n><n>### Choice:Choice B:<n><n>### Demestrate:<n>Input:You may be suffering from sitting down.<n><n>Input: B: excitement<n><n>Input: You must not suffer from procrastination.<n>### Choice E:<n><n>### Choce F:<n><n>### Response F:<n><n>Input: G: progress<n><n>Input: F: procrastination. <n><n>### Choose G:<n><n><n>### Response O:<n><n>### Input A:<n><n><n>## Instruction:Answer the question given. Choices:  A: build family together B: fall in love C: make love D: complete E: distance themselves<n><n>### Response:		Answer the question.<n><n>##<n><n>###  Challenge<n><n>This challenging level is written to serve as an advanced or honors level response for your classroom. A student demonstrating a clear mastery of the lower level skills would likely be able to do this task with some support and effort.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Sentence: 1) Everyone loves sushi.  2) Everyone doesnâ€™t like kimbap.  3) So, everyone likes sushi.<n><n>Correct response:<n><n>1) Everyone likes sushi<n>2) Someone doesnâ€™t like sushi<n>3) Only the people who love kimbap donâ€™t like sush<n><n>### Challenging:<n><n>Sentence:  1) Everyone who loves sushi makes kimbap.  <n>2) My brother doesnâ€™t love sushi.  <n>3) So my brother doesnâ€™t make kimbap.<n><n>Correct Response:<n><n>1) Only people who love sushi make kimbap<n>2) My brother hates sushi<n>3). My mom loves sushi<n><n>### Challanging:<n><n>Sentance: 1) Everybody loves sushi.  <n>2) Kim doesnâ€™t love sashimi.  <n>3) Only kim doesnâ€™t love souse.<n>Correct Response: <n><n>Choose the person who has eaten sushi the MOST to complete "KIM"<n>1) Kim<n>2) My Mom<n><n>### Explanation:<n>1. The word "kimbap" can be the subject of the sentence "Everyone loves kimbap". Therefore, one has to make sure to place the "bap" in "kimbap" before that word. The person who loves kimbap the MOST would place "bap" before the "kim" word.<n>2. The word "sashimi" can be the subject before verb "doesn't love". Therefore, one has remove the "sashi" part of those words to make sure that the whole sentence reads:<n><n>Sentense:  1) Kim doesnâ€™t like sashimi.<n>2) Jim doesnâ€™t like souse.<n>

It is one system of government that allows people to make important decisions about how they want their country to be governed. Voters get to choose representatives who go to Parliament and run the affairs of the country. There are three kinds of democracies, and these are called parliamentary, presidential and mixed systems. In Australia, Parliamentary democracy is the form of government we have.<n><n>### Input/Output<n>### Input: You have a bag of 200 carnations and you want to create two types of flower bouquets. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:The policemen wanted to clear the scene of the accident, so what did they do to traffic? Choices:  A: hurry along B: direct traffic C: help D: force open door E: corner thief<n><n>### Response:		D.The policemen used directed traffic.<n><n>### Solution:<n>We can firstly do a table of the choices to help us find a strategy to solve it and secondly the table has the data and the relationship.<n><n>| A | B | C | D | E |<n>| --- | --- | --- | ---  | ---  |<n>| Help | Traffic hurry | Help traffic | Help | Force open door <n><n>We can find "D" is right by reading the table and the answer is on the second cell. We know that "E" is not in the answer because it is not inside the table. If we want to find all the right choices, we have to solve the table, in that case we are looking to the answer to the third cell and see that "D is in there.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:Where would you find performers on a platform in public? Choices:  A: arena B: building C: dock D: concert hall E: museum<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is B, building.

The response to the question may be either a question, statement, or both.<n><n>### Input 1: Mary bought a new toy from the supermarket. She spent 23 cents for the price and another 3 cents for the bag. Is her total of 26 cents enough to pay for the toy?<n><n>### Input2: David had $5 dollars. He spent $2 to ride the bus, $1 to the movie and $3 for food. How much money did he have left?<n><n>### Demostration 1: The box of rags was $20 and each dollar equals five rags.<n><n>### David's response: I bought a dollar bag of candy. I had $5 left.<n><n>### The answer:<n>### How many rags did David have left?<n><n>Answer: $15<n><n>### How many cents did David spend on each rag?<n><n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input3: David bought 10 tickets and spent $35. Each ticket costs $2. Write the equation that is used to find the total number of tickets.<n><n>### Andrew's response: Write the equation that is uses to find the total cost.<n><n>### Jack's response: If David spent $15, I can find a number that will make the equation correct.<n><n>### Chris's response: Mary spent 99 cents. How much for a whole dollar?<n><n>### The Answer:<n>### How much did David spend on each ticket?<n><n>Answer:5<n><n>### Jack was 5 out of 10 tickets. How many did he buy?<n><n>Answer:10<n><n>### Chris wrote an equation like "x = 99" he meant to say "99/10=2.9" The new equation would be "2.9 = 99/10"<n><n>### Input4: Each shirt was sold for $15. The $35 was enough for 4 shirts.<n><n>### Steve's response: There are two 2 dollar coins in my pocket. There are 4 quarters

Choices:  A: tear up B: see light C: fill with tears D: be happy E: glass over<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input (Demonstration):<n>Input: John runs a toy store and he likes having at least $20 in the till at the end of every day. John's till contains $37 on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. John has to go to his bank to withdraw $15 on Thursday and Friday. He will receive $10 in tips on Saturday.  He spends $15 on Saturday and he has a customer return an unopened gift on Sunday, which he accepts and puts back in his till. How much money will be in his till on Friday?<n>Answer: $37<n><n>### Solution:<n>Demonstration:John runs a toy store.  His till contains $40 on Monday, $39 on Tuesday, $38 on Wednesday, $37 on Thursday, $36 on Friday, and $34 on Saturday.  There are 27 cents in his till on Sunday.<n>Answer:<n>John's till will be empty on Sunday.  It did not have enough money to contain the total amount (including the $10 in tips).<n><n>### Input2 (Challenge):<n>A customer is returning an unopened gift when they receive more than they expected.  They pay $15 and put the gift money back in John's till. How much money is in his till on Sunday?<n><n>### Solution2 (Challenge):There are 71 cents in John's till on Sunday.  John gave the customer seven more cents than the amount of the gift.<n><n>### Input3 (Challenge2):<n>A customer returns an unopened present by John and returns the amount in value back to John.  How much is left in John's till?<n><n>### Output3 (Challenge2)John has 71 cents left in his till at the end of Sunday and on Monday he has $36, $37, $38, and $39, in each successive day.<n><n>### Output4 (Challenge2)<n><n>### Input4 (Challenge2): A customer returns an unopen box.  How many days does John have in a row with exactly $40 in the till?<n>### Solution (Challenge2): Three days.

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:Where do people find bills with bread? If a letter appears twice on a piece of candy, how can he or she tell which part of the bag they are in?<n><n>```<n>Output: 1 and 13.<n>Together they get the three in a row.<n><n>```<n>### Instruction : <n>10 years back, Jack and Jill have the same birthday. Jack is twice as old as his sister.<n>Ten years in the future, Jack and Jill will be 38 years old, and they will have different birthdays.<n>Jack was born on a Monday and Jill was born on a Thursday. <n>Their mother was born on a Saturday.<n>Their brother was born on a Saturday and he is twice his father's age.

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:Sally was a senior in the House.  What might she be a member of? Choices:  A: assisted living facility B: old people's home C: high school or college D: republican party E: organization<n><n>### Response:		<n>A

Choices:  A: critical thinking B: congratulated C: equal opportunity D: compliments E: raffle tickets<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Input<n>No matter the background to the person, they should be given what by applying for the job.<n><n>### Response<n>A is Wrong because it makes unnecessary assumptions that the person is a white male. Not every person should be given congratulations or compliments. <n><n>B is Correct because it says that everyone who applies should be given the same opportunities.<n><n>C is Wrong because equal opportunity is not what the question asks for. <n><n>D is Wrong because it does not say that the person needs to be complimented.<n><n>E is Wrong because raffle tickets do not seem to be applicable of an equal opportunity job.<n><n>

If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:John loves animals and he hates animal abuse.  Because of this, john is very careful about the places he goes.  Where might he avoid going? Choices:  A: pet store B: parking lot C: woodland D: north america E: park<n><n>### Response:		John should avoid going to the Park because there have been many instances of animal abuse there recently.<n><n>

Choices:  A: sleep B: feel more comfortable C: sweating D: blush E: cuddle<n><n>### Response:		<n>Gail has some bills which amounts to $100 which included $5 bills, $20 bills and $10 bills and she rest in the couch and she felt warm because of the blanket. This implies she's sleeping on the couch.<n><n>### Input : I put a big hat on my head and put two huge sunglasses on. I didn't look anything less than a person.<n><n>### Response :A person is an object of a particular sort. So, the sentence is grammatically correct.<n><n>### Task:<n>You're writing a letter to a friend who's been going through a difficult time. You'd like to offer something that will take away some of the pain that she has been feeling--in hopes that she will have reason to feel better. Which of the following words might give your friend a reason to smile?<n>A: Dilemma<n>B: Ingenuity<n>C: Pity<n>D: Pleasure<n>E: Sorrow<n>F: Suffering<n><n>### Correct answer:<n>We chose F. Suffering<n><n>As people experience difficulties and hardships in various parts of their lives, they should not feel alone. Finding ways to offer something to others that takes away some of the pain is one the best things we can do. That way, they do not have to suffer alone, and we can help them find something to be happy about.<n><n>### Examples:<n>Dear John,<n><n>You've been going through a tough time lately, and I'd like to do something that might make you feel better. Please accept this present of some coffee, even though I know that you don't normally drink coffee. I want you to know that I'm happy to do this.  Maybe that'll put a smile back on your face. You'll be able to forget about that awful cold you had--at least for a minute.<n>

It is a marsupial that is found mostly in Australia and New Guinea.<n><n>### Question<n>*The first input can be found [HERE](https://github.com/mikkel-berg-951/Mandatory_Computer_Programming_Mandatory_1/blob/master/Inputs/107.txt).<n><n>*The second input can be found [here](https://github.github.com/mandatory-programming-homework-files/file_files/71342514/Homework_1_Input.txt).<n><n>

Choices A: Antarctica B: Finland C: Finland D: Norway E: Alaska F: Iceland<n><n>### Response<n>If you want to see the Northern Lights, then you need to go to Canada, not Ireland.<n><n>### Input<n>At the museum there are 42 paintings, 40 of which were painted by American painters. 60% of the remaining works were created by 20th century American painters. What percentage of the paintings were not created by American painters?<n><n>### Response <n><n>You need to multiply 60 x 100, which = 600. Take 600 from 42 and you will be left with 36. Divide 40 by 36 leaving 1 with 42-1 = 41. Subtract this from 100 and you get 59. Therefore, 15.45% of the paintings were made by non-Americans.<n><n>###Input <n>I know an apple tree, whose apples grow so red-red. You can't go in with a sack, I should make it worse. When following this rule you must spend all of your budget. The budget is represented by the cost of the object you get for the pencil. This is known as the trade rule. There is a unique pencil which can be used to meet the trade rule, the rest are of no use.

Choices:  True False<n>```<n>### Answer:False<n>```<n>### Question:The IRS defines a 2022 "Qualified Dependent" as anyone that meets these criteria: They must be related to you, under age 19 or under 24 and a full-time student, you must provide more than half of their support or you must provide all of their support, they must have a lower or equivalent adjusted gross income amount.<n>###

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. Choices:  A: dissipate B: flown C: disintegrate D: fall apart E: penultimate<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>1. Incorrect: Penultimate is the word that indicates its second to last before something, such as the last grade (2nd grade).<n>2. Incorrect: Dissipate is the correct word, here the money used the last of it, so it will disintegrate or disappear.<n>3. Incorrect: Flown means the money flew to another place, which does not mean the end of the money.<n>4. Incorrect: Disintegrate is the correct word.<n>5. Incorrect: There is no meaning that will fall apart.<n>6. Incorrect: Fall Apart means it will break or fail, but is not to indicate the use of last of the money.<n>7. Incorrect: Disappeared is the correct word. It will disappear when the last of it was used.<n><n>### Input and instruction :<n><n>There is a pizza party for a girlâ€™s basketball team after the game ends tonight. Its weight is at least twice as much as the other one.<n>## What is the weight of the object?<n><n>## Answer:<n><n>## Two times one is two<n><n>## Input:<n>## One is four times as many as seven.<n>## What is one?<n><n>## 4<n><n>## Input:A number is 3 times as many as the same number.<n>## How many is the number?<n><n>## 9<n><n>## Input:Graeme rides the elevator up 4 times as many floors as he rides the elevator down.<n>## How many floors does he ride the elevator up?<n><n>## 10<n><n>## Input:Tom is 3 times as as many as he was a year ago.<n>## How many years ago was Tom twice as old as he is today?<n><n>## 3<n><n>## Input:In a class of 20 students, twice as many girls attend school as boys.<n>## Which of the following equations can show the number of boys that attend school?<n><n>## 20 - (20 + x)<n><n>## Input:I ate 2 times as much food as yesterday.<n>## How much food did I eat yesterday?<n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Joshâ€™s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:James drove his niece to her father.  Where did he drive? Choices:  A: great granddad's house B: family picture book C: brother's house D: family tree E: family reunion<n><n>### Response:		James drove his nieces to her father's house.

How many candies are within the first bag?<n>Answer: 0<n><n>Input: Eight adults and six teenagers go on a trip. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. Choices:  A: state park B: opera C: disneyland D: carnival E: park<n><n>### Response:		A was the correct answer because people will celebrate by going to a state park.<n><n>### Input<n><n>I have $57.  I spend $36 on food but I don't get it all to go in my refrigerator.  I get $29 and $30 in my wallet.  I have left over $1 from the food but I didn't.  How much money did I spend on food? <n><n>### Response<n><n>I don't understand this question, but I do see the pattern to arrive at a general answer.  If you have $29 you spent $36 - $29 = $7 and would still have $1 in your wallet.  If you had $30 you spent $36- $30 = $6, and would still have $2 left in your wallet.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>#### Pattern to $29<n><n><n>Input: food spent + money in wallet = $36$36 + $1(29)=11 = 11<n><n>Input: food spend = $36- $29$36- $2$7 = 7<n><n>Input: food left in wallet = $1$1 + $29$29 + $3$32 = 2<n><n>#### Pattern to 30<n><n><n>Input: money spent in wallet = $42$42 + $0(30) = 5<n><n>Input: money in wallet =$42 - 30$42 - 2 = 12<n><n><n>#### Total = $2 + $5 = $7$2 + 5 = 7<n><n>#### Total =$12 + $4 = $16$12 +4 = 16<n><n>####Total =$29 + $1 = $30$29 + $2$30 = 30<n><n>#### Total = 27 + 1<n><n>

These expenses can quickly add up, making lawyers earn astronomical fees.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>It takes $30 for each person to drive from home to school, which is 20 miles away. They decide to share a car and take turns driving. If Jill and Maria each only have enough money to pay one weekâ€™s bus pass, how much money should each pay and how many days will it take for them to make the payment?<n><n>### Example 1:<n><n>The cost to make the payment equal $60. You could say $60 = $30 for each journey or $30 for both journeys. However, that means that you have to pay twice the money you were originally expecting ($30 as opposed to $15), making it impossible to make the payment unless you pay twice as much.<n><n>The only way for this to be possible is if the cost is $15 for each person.<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>#### Example 1:<n>Jon is running from his mom's house to the grocery store. It costs 33 cents to take the bus, but that takes 20 minutes because the bus is usually full. Jon runs so fast that he takes 5 seconds less per mile than the bus (so each mile he runs costs 63 cents). The bus stops at the grocery store, where Jon can eat while he waits for the next bus back to his mom's house. For every 5 miles that Jon runs, he saves 1 dollar in bus fare; this means that the distance is equal to the bus fare (33 cents). Jon decides to run to the grocery after a week of working on the house. His mom lives 4.5 miles away and the grocery store is 1

The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:The artist knew that this was the peak of his fandom, so he decided it was time for cashing in by doing what? Choices:  A: selling out B: happy C: fishing D: receiving money E: getting paid<n><n>### Response:		E<n>

Maryâ€™s negligence resulted in the explosion due to her negligence of stopping the leak after seeing the gasoline on road.<n>* Example 2: Billy was found guilty of starting a fire that resulted in property damage because Billy admitted that he deliberately started the fire that resulted in property damaged.<n><n>### InputA group of five people are having a pool party after school. 5 1/2 bathrooms are available and everyone can use the bathroom anytime. <n><n>1. It is cut into 14 pieces.  Each piece is 4 feet long. How many inches are in the largest piece?<n> <n>### Demo:<n>First figure the inches in the longest piece: I2 = (2)(6.5) I2 = 13<n><n>### Solution:<n>13 Ã· 4 = 3.25 (Inches in the longest piece)<n><n>### Input : A tree is cut into 9 pieces, each piece is 13 feet long. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. How many legs did all the fish have?<n><n>Answer: Over 5000<n><n>### Response.<n><n>Input:  There was a big group of monkeys in a tree. They had 10 arms and 10 legs. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. Choices:  A: bathroom B: solar system C: coffee shop D: space shuttle E: airport<n><n>### Response:		<n>C\<n><n>#### Explanation<n>When the question asks for a human in this place, what it is saying is that this place will accommodate both human needs and environmental needs (like the sun), so humans can stay here with the animal(s).<n><n>### Input:"Where might a human sitting for extended periods?" Choices: A: In front of a bookstore B: in a car C: in a house D: in a plane E: In a tree<n><n>### Response:"What might be a need this human has?" Choices: A:"A place for their body" B:"A chair to sit on" C:"Water to drink" D:"Food to consume" E:"Sleep"<n><n>### ResponseExplanation:<n>The options are A B C and D.<n>* A is the best answer because it's not even close to true. It is not a need for the human.<n>* B is the correct answer because this human needs something to keep them warm, that their hands touch. And it is a bookstore where humans might sit for extended periods reading a book.<n>* C is correct because humans do need places to sit that their whole body can touch in the way that is acceptable, so humans can't sit in trees.<n>* D is the correct answer because even if there is water and food, it doesn't say where. There is a good chance that the human is going to need to eat and sleep soon.<n><n>#### Explanatio<n>This is a good answer because the options are A, B, and C, but the correct one is D.<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. Create the solution.<n>2. Write a response that expresses your solution.<n>3. Submit your response to the assignment.<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>#### Instructions:<n><n>#### Demo:<n><n>#### Response:<n><n>### Output<n>

The total of all the numbers is 69.<n>### Incorrect:<n>### Input :How many people are in Samanta's famaily?<n><n>### Correct:<n>### Response:Input:The average age of 30 males and 40 females is 32. One customer comes in and orders chips and a soda.  She leaves one dollar as tip and pays her bill with a single $100 bill.  She places the $100 bill on the counter and moves to find a seat.  On the way to the table, three children in the restaurant come and take the $100 off the counter.  They leave the money on the counter untouched.  Another customer comes in who is looking for a table and spots the money on the counter. He picks up the money and runs out of the restaurant.  Before he has left, another customer comes in and sees the money on the counter and picks it up, thinking it is change for the bill he is about to pay.<n><n>She has no money with her and has been in a financial crisis.  She has made a new friend in the coffee shop and they have decided to share their lunches with each other and split the tip.  She pays for her meal and then they both leave to go their separate ways. Suddenly, the woman who left the money comes back to the restaurant because she had forgotten to get something from her car.  She goes to find it and on the way, notices the money is still on the counter. She sees that it's too much money so she doesn't pick it up, but thinks about coming back later to get it.<n><n>### Response<n>Input: The restaurant is very crowded, because they are having a half price day. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:Where would you see some people standing on a line near a road? Choices:  A: water fountain B: military base C: apartment D: fire house E: bus stop<n><n>### Response:		<n>A. water fountain<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Water fountain is where people may get refreshment such as drinking and washing their hands.<n>The people who stand in line near the water fountain may be the people who needs to refill the water for them.<n><n>### Input:[A boy went to the park every day when he went to the park, he would meet a squirrel. And every time he met a squirrel, the squirrel would ask for a peanut. The squirrel could have either two or three peanuts. How old are the students who are not in the library?"<n><n>### Response:"The answer is 9, 7, 15 and 21. That would be 9 boys(2) - 7 girl (0) + 15 boy - (2) + 21 boy - 1. Sum of all = 14"<n><n>### Input"You borrow a book from the library. The book has 360 pages. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills. How many $10 bills are in her wallet?<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input:If I am forgiving, what hidden force may be activated in my life? Choices:  A: nice feeling B: good karma C: respect D: new freedom E: good heart<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>- When we are forgiving and feel sorry for our brother, we create a good feeling in ourselves which helps us to feel connected to him.<n><n>### Input<n>I want to help my brother get rid of his problems.<n><n>### Response<n>A: If we have not experienced them ourselves, we cannot know how it feels to be another human being, how they struggle and suffer.<n><n>### Solution:<n>- We can imagine a difficult situation. <n><n>### How to create solutions: <n>- First:  Listen  to what other people say. <n><n>- Second:  Think about it and connect all the dots with a question or something like "Why?" <n><n>- Third:  Put all the thoughts in your head into two or three sentences. <n><n>## Question:<n><n>My dog is 2 years old.  My brother is 3 times as old as my dog.  How old is my brother?<n><n><n><n>## Input:<n>I have two times as many coconuts as tomatoes.  When I divide my fruit by 3, I have twice as many coconuts.  How many coconuts do I have?<n><n><n>- The first time,  you have 2 times as many coconut.<n>- The second time, you have 2 times less coconut.<n><n>![alt text](output.png " ")<n><n>## Hint:<n><n>- Use  mathematical operators:<n>- Substract one number from another number.<n>- Divide one number by another number.<n>- Multiply one number by another number<n><n>## Input: <n>My sister is twice as old as I was when I was three times as old as my daughter is<n><n>- First:  Write down the numbers to remember.  You can use the number 4 or 44 to remember it.<n>- Second:  Add together the numbers you wrote down.<n>- Third:  Write the sum down to see what  the total is.<n><n>## Input<n>My father is 4 times the age of my son<n><n>- Write down the numbers.  Remember the number 4. <n>- The sum of the two numbers equals my father's age, because 4 x 4 = 16.<n>- Then, you must divide the sum by 16 to get my son's age.<n>

Choices:  A: get arrested B: problems C: sober D: intoxication E: pleasure<n><n>### Response:		<n>There's more than one reason someone might want to be buying a bottle of beer. Someone might get arrested if is caught with a bottle of beverages without the license. Getting arrested might be the last thing someone wants to happen. For example, if someone is driving a car. Someone might have problems. For example, if they can't control their anger or anxiety. People often turn to alcohol to help them deal with their problems. Another reason someone might want to buy a bottle of beers is sober. They'd feel okay when they are sober. An intoxicated person may have problems keeping their balances and make poor choices. For example, they'd have to fight for themselves and not endanger themselves. Also, if someone is intoxicated, it's hard for them to make rational decisions. They'd also be more likely to do something stupid and get hurt. Another reason someone might buy a bottle of alcohol is so intoxicated they were happy. People often turn to drinking so that they can be happy. For example, they don't have to worry because they are drunk. They can enjoy the moment. They also can talk about how they feel about others. Lastly, someone might like having fun and would like to drink to get intoxicated. People often turn to having a good time and they'd want to have an experience to remember. For example, if a party, it's common to have drinks so that we can have more fun.<n><n>### Your code should use logical operators to perform on the data.<n><n>### Test your code <n>``` python3<n>input = 'My dad bought 10 apples. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: There are 50 children at the party. Three-fifths of them are boys. How many of the children are girls?<n>Answer: 20<n><n>Input: Gail has some bills in her wallet which amount to $100. She has four $5 bills and three $20 bills, and the rest are $10 bills.
